Il a aussi permis la promotion, le déploiement et I'adoption d'autres pratiques agro-écologiques d'adaptation aux changements climatiques comme la fabrication de compost à partir de résidus de la cacao-culture et son usage, l'usage de séchoirs améliorés pour les fèves de cacao, maximisant l'énergie solaire et la circulation d'air.

It was a very focused project, dealing with cocoa producers, cooperatives and climate experts to develop climate scenarios and decision support tools that promised to be useful into the future at least within the Ivorian context and hopefully in a broader context in West Africa.

L'équipe a quand même su s'adapter rapidement à la nouvelle situation, et a modifié certaines activités, par exemple des ateliers de consultation des usagers ont été remplacés par des consultations à distance (questionnaire et entretiens téléphoniques).

Le développement de l'outil d'aide à la décision a été particulièrement intéressant car il a impliqué toutes les étapes, à partir de la production des scénarios climatiques, leur interprétation et l'analyse des pratiques agro-écologiques d'adaptation des producteurs, le tout constituant un exercice compréhensif de vulgarisation des impacts des changements climatiques. Son développement a impliqué la participation de coopératives cacaoyères, incluant leur conseil d'administration, leur personnel, des représentantes et représentants de leurs comités ainsi que d'autres personnes participantes de façon à refléter la diversité des membres de chaque coopérative et en s'assurant d'une participation féminine.

outcomes.description: The project successfully strengthened capacity to promote gender equality and inclusion in climate adaptation across multiple actor groups throughout its implementation. Research partners (SOCODEVI, Ouranos, WASCAL/CEA-CCBAD), national institutions (ANADER, CNRA), and participating cocoa cooperatives demonstrated improved understanding of gender equality concepts and their integration into research, communication, and operational practices. Cocoa cooperatives made institutional changes by revising their statutory and regulatory provisions, strategic documents, and operational plans to anchor gender equality objectives alongside climate change adaptation goals, with two of three cooperatives adopting these changes in extraordinary general assemblies. The project developed a gender-sensitive decision-support tool and implemented culturally appropriate strategies ensuring meaningful women's participation in research and cooperative governance, including governance training that enabled cooperatives to implement gender-specific measures. Key achievements included improved women's access to resources and decision-making in cocoa production at both family and cooperative levels, enhanced participation in climate adaptation strategies, and the integration of differentiated needs of women and men in selecting adaptation practices such as tree planting and agroecological techniques.

outcomes.description: The project achieved sustained institutional transformations in gender equality across three participating cocoa cooperatives in Côte d'Ivoire. All three cooperatives revised their founding documents, internal regulations, and operational planning documents to formally embed gender equality commitments and climate adaptation objectives, influencing committee composition, decision-making processes, and service delivery to address differentiated needs of women and men members. These statutory and regulatory changes were formally adopted in extraordinary general assemblies in two of the three cooperatives (with the third planned for adoption at its next annual general assembly), representing structural reforms that institutionalize gender considerations into cooperative governance. The project successfully integrated gender equality considerations into cooperative decision-making processes and contributed to better access for women to resources necessary for climate adaptation, with Specific Objective 5 being fully achieved. The institutional reforms included restructuring existing services and creating new services to respond to the distinct needs of female and male members, such as building consolidation work and advocacy for rural road rehabilitation.

outcomes.description: Female PhD fellows supported by the project developed and tested multiple innovations addressing food systems and development challenges in East Africa. One fellow created an AI tool for storytelling and archiving African myths, legends, and folktales, which became the basis for a start-up called LESOStories, with the fellow also using this innovation to inspire tech designer students at a Nairobi University. Another fellow produced educational videos on Water and Cities in Nairobi for N*Gen Television, a channel with wide viewership among children, effectively communicating climate and urban development issues to young audiences. These innovations demonstrate how the fellows applied their research to create tangible solutions and tools that address food security, climate resilience, and knowledge preservation challenges in the region.

outcomes.description: The project established and strengthened multiple networks and partnerships for early-career African women researchers in gender, agriculture, and food security. outcomes.description: The project developed and piloted resources with local actors to promote healthy diets through human rights-based approaches (HRBA), representing the testing of new tools and approaches with stakeholder involvement. A Conceptual and Analytical Framework (CAF) was developed and applied to produce context-specific analyses in Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda, resulting in three country reports and country-specific evidence briefs produced in collaboration with local researchers and stakeholders. These resources and tools were piloted through formal and informal capacity development initiatives, including regional training sessions, policy discussions, focus group discussions, and regional dialogue events. The development and piloting process enhanced learning, strengthened capacities, and promoted collaboration among local actors, improving understanding of how HRBA can advance regulatory and policy measures to promote healthier food environments and prevent diet-related diseases.

outcomes.description: This project generated comprehensive southern-based research and evidence on healthy, sustainable, and climate-resilient food systems in Kenya, with a particular focus on the role of micro and small enterprises (MSEs) in food retail. The research produced multiple high-quality outputs including 5 policy briefs (at national and county levels), 1 blog, and research findings that addressed key knowledge gaps regarding interventions and policy measures to support MSEs, consumer preferences and demand for healthy and sustainable foods, and the enabling environment affecting business decisions. Key research findings included evidence on gender dynamics showing women-owned food retail MSEs significantly outperformed male counterparts, the critical role of MSEs as the most influential actors in local food systems (providing two-thirds of food consumed), barriers to healthy and sustainable food access, policy gaps and incoherent regulations, and household consumption patterns. The project fully met all four specific research objectives related to understanding perceptions and barriers within the enabling environment, effects of businesses on food availability and affordability, factors influencing consumer preferences, and conveying new knowledge on policy measures—all with explicit attention to gender dimensions throughout.

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested a communications framework and audience segmentation approach as innovations to influence food consumption patterns and promote healthier food environments in Tanzania. Through extensive quantitative and qualitative data collection covering all administrative and climatic zones of the country, the project co-developed a communications framework with diverse stakeholders including researchers, journalists, food and nutrition experts, public health specialists, gender experts, and communications experts. The audience segmentation analysis identified 5 distinct audience segments with detailed profiles on socio-cultural and economic factors, food consumption beliefs and habits, media consumption patterns, and advocacy behaviors, enabling much more targeted communication approaches to reach key parts of the population who have different roles in influencing food consumption. This framework and segmentation innovation is being integrated into BBC Media Action's online and radio programming in Tanzania with the potential to reach large audiences and amplify consumer voices on healthier food environments.
outcomes.geography: Tanzania (all administrative zones, including rural and urban areas, different climatic zones, and target regions with specific nutritional concerns such as high rates of obesity, overweight, stunting and climate-related food shortages)
outcomes.target_population: Vulnerable communities and consumers in Tanzania including women and men in diverse contexts; stakeholders comprised of researchers, journalists, food and nutrition experts, public health specialists, gender experts, communications experts; BBC Media Action research team members and freelancers; individuals and communities across rural and urban areas represented in the 5 audience segments
quotes: A key output of this workshop was a communications framework, codeveloped by the stakeholders in attendance (comprised of researchers, journalists, food and nutrition experts, public health specialists, gender experts and commmunications experts). This communication framework is expected to be used across content of the BBC Media Action team in Tanzania, which includes online and radio programming, that can help to increase awareness and amplify consumer voices on healthier food environments.

Through the audience segmentation and communications framework activities, the project was able to identify much more targeted communication approaches to reach key parts of the populace, all of whom have different roles to play in influencing food consumption and the wider food environment.

outcomes.description: The project established and strengthened multiple equitable partnerships and networks for knowledge sharing on food systems and nutrition in Tanzania. Research data and insights were shared publicly with researchers, civil society organizations, and media organizations working in the food systems, health, and nutrition space, strengthening the broader network. The integration of the final dissemination workshop into BBC Media Action's international INSIGHTFUL festival in September 2024 expanded the network to a broader international audience, while the co-development of a communications framework with diverse Tanzanian stakeholders (researchers, journalists, food and nutrition experts, public health specialists, gender experts, and communications experts) exemplified multi-actor collaboration for sustained impact.

outcomes.description: This research support project produced 43 high-quality commissioned reports and documents, including 23 disease monographs on livestock diseases and vaccine research, situation analyses on legislative/regulatory/veterinary support systems, manufacturing capacity studies for Africa and Asia, stakeholder consultation reports from multiple countries, environmental management plans, and a comprehensive scoping studies summary document. The disease monographs and other outputs were published on the IDRC library and served as valuable reference documents for livestock vaccine development, informing LVIF's call for proposals and being used by external partners including Global Affairs Canada for their Ag Results program. The research identified key stakeholders in vaccine development, regulation, production and distribution across focus countries, provided contextual information on manufacturing capabilities in LMICs, and generated recommendations around packaging, thermostability, and quality assurance. These knowledge products enabled the LVIF program and broader field to understand the livestock vaccine landscape, local contexts for vaccine development, and needs of smallholder farmers, while positioning IDRC as a leader in livestock health research and informing future programming in climate-resilient livestock systems.

outcomes.description: The project generated substantial new knowledge and high-quality research evidence on obesogenic food environments in South Africa and Ghana, producing 6 peer-reviewed publications, 8 digital stories, and 1 documentary video that enhanced understanding of factors contributing to unhealthy food environments. The research developed innovative methodologies for food environment assessment, including novel qualitative methods in nutrition research that were shared through workshops (such as one with 35 attendees at the International Congress of Dietetics). Key scientific findings included evidence on how modernization and urbanization drive shifts toward processed foods, gendered analyses showing links between food purchaser gender and consumption patterns (with implications for health risks), and insights into food value chains revealing limited access to healthy foods for the poor and aggressive marketing of unhealthy options. project_name: INSFEED2: Insect Feed for Poultry, Fish and Pig Production in Sub-Saharan Africa

outcomes.description: The INSFEED2 project generated extensive high-quality research evidence on insect-based feed systems and climate-resilient agriculture across multiple dimensions. The project produced at least 11 major research publications covering socio-economic and environmental implications of insect-based feeds, gender-specific preferences, low-cost waste recycling technologies, frass fertilizer applications, and animal health benefits. Key scientific findings included comprehensive nutritional analysis of BSF larvae reared on 19+ organic waste categories (showing 33-62% crude protein), development of over 53 feed formulations tested on-farm and on-station, and analysis of bacterial and fungal communities in BSF gut for food safety measures. The research also generated evidence on value-added products (frass fertilizer, chitin/chitosan extraction, insect oils), demonstrated substantial economic impacts (potential creation of 25,000-252,000 jobs in poultry sector, 5-15 fold income increases for farmers using frass fertilizer), and informed the development of three pioneering national standards for insect-based feed production and products—the first such standards published globally.
quotes: The evidence generated by the project indicates the potential of transforming livelihoods if the insect for feed industry is well utilised. For example, substituting current fish and soybean protein with insect meal in the entire poultry sector would create 25,000 – 252,000 jobs of which 3300-33,000 new jobs would specifically be in the commercial poultry sector.

BSF when reared on over nineteen organic waste categories had high crude protein (33% - 62%), fats (25 - 49%), minerals and vitamins that are comparable to that of fishmeal or superior to that of most plant sources, offering an excellent alternative to fishmeal and soya bean.

outcomes.description: The INSFEED2 project involved smallholder farmers, women, and youth in developing, piloting, and testing multiple climate-resilient food system innovations centered on black soldier fly (BSF) technology. Key innovations included three distinct business models (cyclic, market-driven, and out-grower models) with 77%, 18%, and 5% adoption rates respectively among insect farmers; over 53 feed formulations tested on-farm and on-station in partnership with local government authorities; efficient BSF larvae processing techniques (steaming at 84°C for 5 min, drying at 120°C for 2h:30); and three value-added products including frass fertilizer for improved soil fertility and crop yields, chitin/chitosan extraction from BSF pupal exuviae for animal health applications, and insect oils rich in omega-3 fatty acids. The project also developed three pioneering national standards (KS 2921:2020, KS 2922 Part 1 and Part 2) for insect-based feed production and handling, representing the first such standards published as National Standards globally. Through these innovations, vulnerable communities including women (31% of insect farmers) and youth (1,325 employed) meaningfully participated in co-creating and testing technologies, practices, and business models that enhance climate resilience and sustainable protein production for livestock and fish farming.

Over 103 private companies and young entrepreneurs established BSF farming enterprises for commercial production, with major producers like InsectPro Farm producing over 60 tons of dried BSF per month and Sanergy Ltd producing over 250 tons per month for national and export markets. Farmers actively adopted three distinct business models: 77% practice the cyclic model (producing BSF and using it in their own pig and poultry farms), 18% use the market-driven model (producing for market and negotiating prices), and 5% practice the out-grower model (small-scale farmers producing under contractual arrangements with larger businesses). outcomes.description: The project produced substantial high-quality research evidence on picture-based insurance (PBI) effectiveness and climate-resilient food systems in Kenya, including evaluation results demonstrating that PBI more than doubled insurance uptake among smallholder farmers with effects concentrated among female farmers. The research outputs included multiple peer-reviewed publications, literature reviews on gender-inclusive agricultural insurance, pilot studies on seed delivery systems, field experiments on climate-smart crop insurance, and studies on edutainment interventions for gender equity and intra-household decision-making. Machine learning models were developed and tested achieving prediction accuracies of 75% for growth stage classification, 89% for visible drought classification, and 86% for extent of drought predictions to automate image analytics for insurance claims. Additionally, champions collected close to 65,000 crop images for seasonal crop monitoring which were published online and made publicly accessible at https://mlhub.earth/data/lacuna_fund_eotg_v1 for further research use. The research demonstrated innovative approaches to reduce verification costs, address basis risk in agricultural insurance, and design gender-responsive insurance products that improved farmers' trust, perceptions of product quality, and willingness to invest in productivity-enhancing inputs.

outcomes.description: Smallholder farmers in Kenya were directly involved in developing, co-creating, piloting, and testing the picture-based insurance (PBI) innovation, a climate-smart crop insurance product that uses smartphone technology and image analysis to assess individual crop damage. Over 36,000 farmers (61% female) participated in testing the innovation by submitting 65,000 crop images through smartphones for automation testing, which provided the foundation for developing machine learning models to automate verification of drought damage with prediction accuracies of 75% for growth stage classification, 89% for visible drought classification, and 86% for extent of drought predictions. The testing phases resulted in insurance uptake growing from 87 policies in short rains 2021 to over 5,000 policies by long rains, with 8,500 total climate smart insurance policies provided and 3,672 insurance payouts made. The project employed a champion farmer model where both male and female champions were trained and equipped with smartphones to help create awareness, train farmers on good agricultural practices, and collect demand for inputs, with female champions successfully reaching 65% female farmers compared to 55% reached by male champions. The innovation testing also included developing a hybrid PBI product combining weather index-based insurance with picture-based monitoring to reduce basis risk, and pilot studies on inclusive seed delivery bundled with insurance services, with plans to scale up the tested innovation to Rwanda and Malawi.

outcomes.description: The project improved understanding among multiple stakeholder groups about effective climate-resilient insurance solutions for smallholder farmers. Decision-makers and researchers gained insights into how picture-based insurance (PBI) addresses the failures of traditional indemnity and index-based insurance by reducing basis risk and verification costs through smartphone technology and image processing. The research demonstrated the critical importance of gender-responsive design features, showing that women's willingness to pay for insurance decreased by 29% when payouts were controlled by spouses and by 54% when controlled by ROSCAs, informing future insurance policy design for women farmers who often lack personal mobile money accounts. KALRO worked to have PBI included in the review of national Insurance policy to ensure the technology can be commercialized and made accessible to farmers and insurance companies. The project showed how artificial intelligence and machine learning can automate crop damage assessment with 75-89% accuracy, reducing assessment delays and making agricultural insurance more viable, with potential for scale-up to Rwanda and Malawi.
quotes: WTP fell substantially if the payout was controlled by someone other than the policyholder. This is important in the design of insurance policies that target women farmers, who are less likely to have their personal mobile money accounts.

outcomes.description: The project established innovative and equitable public-private partnerships where the private sector (ACRE Africa) served as the principal organization with research organizations (KALRO, Wageningen, IFPRI) as third parties, reversing typical arrangements. These partnerships facilitated south-south learning between Kenya and India, with IFPRI bringing expertise from picture-based insurance experiences in India and establishing linkages with Indian firms (Dvara E-Registry and GESA) to support automation of image processing. The project also created equitable networks through deliberately recruiting a well-balanced mix of male and female champion farmers representative of the target population, with female champions proving particularly effective at reaching women farmers (65% of their registrations were female compared to 55% for male champions). This gender-responsive network approach ensured each partner brought its core function to the project and increased inclusivity in delivering the insurance innovation to marginalized groups, particularly women farmers who often lack access to technology and financial services.

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity to promote gender equality and inclusion in agricultural insurance through multiple approaches. First, it developed gender-responsive insurance product design approaches, including the use of female "champion farmers" who were trained to market and distribute products, use smartphones to collect crop images, and leverage their social networks to reach women farmers—resulting in female champions registering 21,321 farmers (65% female) compared to male champions registering 14,986 farmers (55% female). Second, the project addressed structural barriers by training champions on reaching women farmers despite smartphone access differences, ensuring women farmers registered for mobile money wallets to directly access insurance payouts rather than through spouses or other accounts—research showed willingness to pay decreased by 29% when payment went to a spouse's account and 54% when made to a ROSCA. Third, a complementary gender edutainment intervention developed by Mediae challenged existing gender norms and roles, improved joint decision-making, and helped reduce instances of gender-based violence occasioned by control over assets. These integrated approaches improved women's interest in and access to agricultural insurance, high-quality seeds, and new seed varieties.
quotes: In addition, a complementary gender edutainment intervention developed by Mediae—producers of a popular TV show Shamba Shape Up—challenged existing gender norms and roles, and improved joint decision-making to help reduce instances of gender-based violence occasioned by control over assets.

project_name: Amplifying the uptake of African adaptation science in the 6th Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)

outcomes.description: The project produced high-quality, African-based research and evidence on climate change impacts and adaptation that resulted in "the strongest assessment of African climate evidence ever contained in an IPCC report." Key research outputs included the IPCC AR6 Working Group II Africa Chapter (Ch.09) and Decision-making Options chapter (Ch.17), along with multiple path-breaking publications: the first Africa-wide assessment of climate change adaptation feasibility and effectiveness, the first continent-wide assessment of climate change literacy rates, a continent-wide analysis of climate change research funding since 1990, and a groundbreaking framework on complex climate change risks (Simpson et al. 2021). The project also produced regional fact sheets for Southern, Central, West, East, and North Africa (in English, French, and Portuguese) synthesizing IPCC findings for policy audiences. This synthesis work elevated African research into thought leadership positions within the IPCC Summary for Policymakers on topics including climate finance, complex climate change risk, solar geoengineering, and climate change literacy.
quotes: Helped to generate the strongest assessment of African climate evidence ever contained in an IPCC report.

outcomes.description: African researchers (Dr. Trisos, Dr. Simpson, and Dr. Totin) led a ground-breaking cross-IPCC project that developed and synthesized a new "Complex Climate Change Risk Framework" to better understand how climate risks compound and cascade across multiple sectors. This innovative framework was published in Simpson et al. 2021 and influenced the approach to risk assessment throughout the entire IPCC Sixth Assessment Report, extending far beyond the Africa Chapter. The framework has been adopted and tested in unexpected policy contexts internationally, including by Belgium's Federal minister for Climate to establish a coordinating body for climate risk analysis reporting to the National Security Council, and by the United States Department of Energy to set their 2030 Vision for risk assessment. This represents a significant example of African thought leadership and innovation in climate science being co-created, tested, and applied not only in Africa but also influencing climate risk assessment approaches in developed countries.

location_country: Senegal, Cape Verde, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger

outcomes.description: The project produced high-quality, southern-based research evidence on the impacts of COVID-19 government response policies on food systems and livelihoods across five West African countries. This included assembling a rich mixed-methods database (quantitative household survey data and qualitative key informant interviews) that analyzed both national and regional policy impacts across different domains, with gender-disaggregated data. The research yielded five national reports analyzing COVID-19 containment measures' impacts on livelihoods, statistical analysis ranking positive and negative effects of public response policies, and contributed to a synthesis report through Food Systems Foresight. The evidence confirmed differential impacts on women versus men, showed that measures protecting existing livelihoods were perceived more positively than transformative interventions, and demonstrated that easing quarantine measures had consistent positive impacts while containment measures had larger negative impacts than the disease itself. Despite limitations in analytical depth (only descriptive statistics, no peer-reviewed publications completed), the knowledge generated provided evidence on how policies can have immediate impacts on food system health and resilience in climate-vulnerable contexts with fragile governance systems.
quotes: The project surveyed extensively the perceived impacts of policy responses to the covid-19 pandemics in the five countries of study. To do so, it assembled a rich database of both impacts of national policies and on those of regional policies in each country. The database is mixed quantitative (households' survey data) and qualitative (key informants' interviews), and it spans across different impact domains.

outcomes.description: The project generated improved understanding of COVID-19 policy impacts on food systems and livelihoods through extensive surveys and data analysis across five Sahel countries, producing a rich mixed quantitative and qualitative database that ranked the positive and negative effects of various COVID-19 response measures. Key insights included that measures protecting existing livelihoods were perceived more positively than transformational interventions, quarantine easing was consistently viewed as beneficial, and certain measures (like emergency cash distribution) had varying effectiveness across contexts—knowledge applicable to future crisis responses including climate-related disaster risk reduction. Results were presented to policymakers in numerous forums with media resonance, and findings were shared with Food Systems Foresight for synthesis work, though the project faced limitations in producing peer-reviewed publications and more advanced statistical analysis. Traditional restitution workshops were held in all five countries, and the project reinforced hypotheses about factors contributing to livelihood weakening during crises, with the Principal Investigator presenting findings in virtual seminars on science-to-policy dialogues and knowledge sharing among francophone research communities.

outcomes.description: The project produced comprehensive, high-quality research evidence and knowledge products on COVID-19's impacts on agropastoral food systems across West and Central Africa. Through rigorous analysis of interviews with 517 agropastoral family farms across 8 countries, a literature review of over 40 publications, and three regional workshops with 91 community leaders, the project generated detailed knowledge on COVID-19 effects on food security, endogenous crisis management mechanisms, and the effectiveness of government response measures. The research outputs included one regional policy brief, eight national policy briefs (one for each country), a comprehensive research report analyzing all collected data, a documentary synthesis, a draft article on COVID-19 effects on agropastoral farms, and a declaration from APESS. The knowledge produced exceeded IDRC's expectations in terms of quality, richness, and depth of analyses, achieving all objectives within a 12-month period and providing evidence to inform more effective responses to future epidemics and food system shocks in low and middle-income countries.

outcomes.description: This project generated comprehensive evidence and policy recommendations that improved decision-makers' understanding of COVID-19 impacts on agropastoral food systems and effective crisis response solutions in West and Central Africa. The research revealed that only 26% of agropastoral family farms benefited from government COVID-19 response plans, with weak involvement of herder organizations in formulation and implementation, leading to specific recommendations for better crisis management including greater stakeholder involvement, improved targeting, and preservation of herder mobility. Eight country-specific policy briefs were developed and disseminated at scale to guide relevant policies for agro-pastoralism across the region. The project also produced critical learnings about rapid assessment methodologies and systems approach research for addressing urgent food security issues, with knowledge products informed by rigorous analysis of data from 517 agropastoral family farms, documentary review, and workshops with 91 community leaders across four ecological zones.

outcomes.description: This project produced a substantial body of high-quality research evidence on fiscal policies for non-communicable disease (NCD) prevention in sub-Saharan Africa, including 9 peer-reviewed articles published as a special issue in the open access journal Global Health Action and 6 Op-Eds published through The Conversation Africa that garnered over 5,500 reads. The research analyzed the policy landscape for sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) taxation across seven countries, examining data availability on NCDs and risk factors, current policy environments, legal feasibility of fiscal interventions, political economy considerations, and the role of the food and beverage industry. Key scientific findings included weak NCD data monitoring systems, lack of NCDs recognition outside the health sector, industry opposition to fiscal policies, but also confirmation that no legal barriers exist to adopting SSB taxes. This research established a critical evidence base for NCD prevention policy in Eastern and Southern Africa and demonstrated exemplary South-South collaboration with field thought leaders, contributing significantly to knowledge on climate-resilient food systems and health policy.

outcomes.description: The project produced extensive southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience and heat stress management in Indian cities, including three scientifically sound Heat Stress Action Plans (HSAPs) for Delhi, Bhubaneswar, and Rajkot that incorporated climatological variations analysis, thermal hotspot mapping, vulnerability mapping, and household surveys. Additionally, the project generated extensive scientific and mass media publications at regional and global levels, established the South Asia Heat Health Information Network (SAHHIN) that has published 13 news mailer issues and delivered five virtual master classes on heat stress management, and produced evidence-based research tools and capacity building modules that informed heat action plans across India and South Asia.

project_name: The Cost of Eating Healthy in Kenya: Comparative Analysis of Healthy versus Unhealthy Foods

outcomes.description: This project produced the first comprehensive quantitative assessment of the cost of eating healthy at a national level in Kenya, generating novel evidence on the relationship between dietary patterns, socioeconomic status, and food costs. The research produced multiple high-quality outputs including four manuscripts for open access journals, a comprehensive study report, a pre-print manuscript on food consumption demand system elasticities, a policy brief, a video animation, a blog post, and coverage in major Kenyan media. Key scientific findings included that eating healthy is associated with higher socioeconomic status (HDI score of 0.46 for wealthiest vs -0.02 for poorest households), that healthy diets cost significantly more (USD 576 per person annually for those meeting 6+ WHO recommendations vs USD 481 for those meeting none), and that women-led households showed better adherence to fruit and vegetable recommendations but at higher costs. This evidence is now available to inform policymakers considering fiscal policies such as reduced taxes or subsidies for healthier foods, and has bolstered APHRC's standing as a leading African research institution focused on the food environment and health nexus.
quotes: As far as we know, this project is the first of its kind to quantitatively assess the cost of eating healthy at a national level in Kenya. Four manuscripts are in the pipeline and are aiming to be published in open access journals.
Wambiya, E., Osindo, J., Kisia, L., Ilboudo, P., and Mohamed, SF. 2021. The Cost of Eating Healthy in Kenya Study Report. African Population and Health Research Center (APHRC); Nairobi, Kenya.

project_name: Building scholarship to guide decisions and governance for interactions between public health and corporate actors

outcomes.description: The project successfully produced high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on governance, ethics, and conflicts of interest in public health and the commercial determinants of health. Key research outputs included two peer-reviewed publications (one in Globalization and Health and one in International Journal of Public Health, which won second-place recognition), a series of 12 webinars, two newsletters, conference presentations at six major international conferences, and seed grants that funded two research projects examining conflicts of interest in food and nutrition research in Ghana and corporate political activity of the food industry in Guatemala and Panama. The project developed locally grounded but globally relevant knowledge on ethical interactions between public health and corporate actors, particularly regarding non-communicable disease (NCD) prevention and food systems, and established a sustainable Southern-led network of practice (GECI-PH Network) with 122 members to support ongoing collaboration and knowledge production. All project objectives related to advancing the research agenda and contributing to the body of knowledge were fully met.
quotes: This project supported GECI-PH to develop locally grounded but globally relevant learnings on this topic, and to advocate for more robust, transparent, and accountable scientific research and public health policymaking.

The team provided seed grants to two research teams. The first project was titled "Conflict of Interest in food and nutrition research in Ghana", led by Dr. Richmond Aryeetey, Associate Professor at the School of Public Health, University of Ghana, and the second project was titled: "Corporate political activity of the food industry in Guatemala and Panamá", led by Dr. Maria Fernanda Kroker-Lobos, Scientific Researcher at the Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama Research Center for the Prevention of Chronic Diseases (CIIPEC).

project_name: South Asian Water (SAWA) Leadership Program on Climate Change

outcomes.description: The SAWA Leadership Program generated substantial high-quality, southern-based research on climate resilience and integrated water resources management (IWRM) in South Asia. The program produced 17 master's theses on IWRM and climate change with gender and social inclusion perspectives, 18 peer-reviewed journal articles led by South Asian fellows, 3 book chapters, and 7 peer-reviewed papers on "Climate Change, Water, and Society" published in a special issue of the journal Water. Additional research outputs included 58 conference presentations, 15 published conference proceedings, 18 field research reports, and multiple blogs. This body of knowledge offers improved understanding of how IWRM approaches can build resilience to climate change impacts through interdisciplinary research methods including gender approaches, addressing water insecurity, adaptation solutions, and sustainable water management across mountainous, coastal, urban, and peri-urban contexts in South Asia.
quotes: The program has, to date, generated 17 master's theses, 18 peer-reviewed journal articles, 3 book chapters, 58 conference presentations and 15 published national and international conference proceedings, 18 field research reports, and 7 peer-reviewed papers on the theme of "Climate Change, Water, and Society," to be published in 2022 in a special issue of the journal Water.

outcomes.description: The SAWA Leadership Program engaged 43 female fellows in developing, co-creating, and testing multiple climate and water system innovations across South Asia. Through intensive regional workshops, fellows practiced and applied participatory research tools (PRA tools) and interdisciplinary field-based research methodologies for climate change and water research, generating practical innovations in water management. Fellows also developed innovative technical solutions through their research, such as new approaches to water distribution systems in irrigation (distributing water to tail reaches rather than head reaches in humid regions) and insights showing that non-system tanks are more efficient than cascade tanks for water management, with implications for large-scale implementation programs.

outcomes.outcome_type: Sustained Gender Equality and Inclusion Transformations
outcomes.description: The project achieved sustained gender equality transformations through the Gender Transformative Farmer Field and Business Schools (GT-FFBS) model, which addressed structural gender inequalities and fostered long-term changes in decision-making power and household dynamics. Women's participation in agricultural decision-making increased significantly, with the proportion of women making most or all decisions in staple grain farming rising from 67% to 79% between baseline and endline. Joint decision-making around family income, expenditure, and marketing became more prevalent, with 54% of women in the gender transformative group reporting being consulted by their spouses on household decisions. Additionally, 25% of women reported increased ability and confidence to provide input on decisions around productive resources, and respondents reported reduced cases of gender-based violence as a result of gender training involving both men and women. These changes contributed to an 8.3% increase in household wealth and income, particularly among women in the GT-FFBS cohort, demonstrating the model's effectiveness in transforming gender power dynamics and reducing structural barriers to women's empowerment.

outcomes.description: The project generated knowledge and empirical evidence supporting Quinoa as a strategic crop to improve resilience and livelihoods in marginal ecosystems in Morocco. Research outputs included four peer-reviewed articles in scientific journals and one conference paper covering topics such as mechanical pearling effects on nutrients and saponin, value chain and marketing assessment, techno-economic assessment, and introduction of high-yielding cultivars. The project also produced training materials (including Quinoa guidelines for farmers in Arabic), press/magazine articles, and website publications that documented innovations in production, processing, and marketing. This localized, evidence-based information demonstrated Quinoa's high tolerance to abiotic stresses, yield improvements (38% under rainfed and 121% under irrigation), cost reductions (28% through mechanization), and enhanced profitability compared to traditional crops like wheat and barley. The research outputs and training materials are being used in ongoing programs by the National Office for Agricultural Advisory Services and informed the development of four additional projects funded by public actors with a combined budget of approximately 2 million CAD.

outcomes.description: Smallholder farmers and cooperatives in Morocco were directly involved in developing, testing, and piloting multiple climate and food system innovations across the quinoa value chain. At the production level, five improved quinoa varieties with high tolerance to abiotic stresses were introduced, evaluated through trials, and tested under real farm conditions, resulting in yield increases of 38% under rainfed agriculture and 121% under irrigation compared to local varieties. At the processing level, innovations included the development and local manufacturing of a pearling machine to remove saponin from quinoa grains, along with three additional machines (thresher, winnower, and washer), which reduced production costs by 28% under rainfed conditions and substantially reduced women's drudgery in processing. At the marketing level, innovations were piloted with six cooperatives (four newly created, including three women-led) and included the creation of Morocco's first group of organic quinoa producers with certification granted in 2019, diversification of quinoa-based products, and facilitation of sanitary authorization enabling one women-led cooperative to market products through a main supermarket supply chain in Morocco.

project_name: Coherence of food and agricultural policies with non-communicable disease prevention in South Africa

outcomes.description: This project produced comprehensive, high-quality research evidence on the coherence between agri-food and health policies in South Africa, marking the first pioneering effort of its kind in Africa to investigate policy incoherence using both quantitative and qualitative approaches. The research analyzed over 60 agri-food and health policies (63 total) and generated new knowledge on multiple dimensions including: policy coherence gaps and lack of multisectoral coordination; fruit and vegetable consumption patterns across different socio-economic groups and genders; value-chain analysis of indigenous fruits and vegetables; and barriers to adequate nutrition. Multiple peer-reviewed journal articles and research outputs were published on topics including farm production diversification, dietary diversity among subsistence farming households, and the role of information technologies in fruit and vegetable consumption. The research established that only about a fifth of South Africa's population consumed the WHO-recommended levels of fruits and vegetables daily, identified insufficient incentives for smallholder farmers to produce and market indigenous fruits and vegetables, and documented specific gender differences in consumption patterns and access to health information.
quotes: The project analysed over 60 agri-food and health policies and found that there was lack of coherence across these policies.
this project is a pioneering effort in Africa to employ both quantitative and qualitative approaches to investigate the level and causes of incoherence between health and agri-food policies

project_name: The Potential Effects of Sugar-Sweetened Beverages Tax on Obesity Prevalence in Tanzania

outcomes.description: This project produced novel, high-quality research evidence on non-communicable diseases (NCDs) and sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) taxation in Tanzania, representing the first research of its kind in Eastern Africa. The research outputs included: (1) evidence on the economic burden of NCDs in Tanzania, showing costs nearly doubled from US$143 million in 2015 to US$281 million in 2019; (2) a mathematical simulation model estimating that a 20% SSB tax would reduce obesity by 6.6% overall (12.9% in adult males, 5.2% in adult females) and increase government revenue by 109%; and (3) gender-differentiated evidence showing SSB taxation impacts men and women differently, with men experiencing more than twice the obesity reduction compared to women. At least 2 peer-reviewed papers are anticipated for publication in open access journals, and the research received substantial media coverage across local Tanzanian newspapers including the Guardian, the Citizen, Nipashe, and the Daily News. This evidence generation positioned the research team as leading voices on fiscal policy for NCD prevention in Sub-Saharan Africa and provides actionable evidence for policymakers considering fiscal policy reforms.

CDKN synthesized IPCC assessment reports into regionally-tailored factsheets and communication toolkits for Africa, Asia, and Latin America, which were viewed over 1,000 times, downloaded 450 times, and used by the African Group of Negotiators during COP27 negotiations. Targeted capacity building initiatives strengthened government officials' understanding of gender integration in climate action (training 20 Ethiopian ministry gender focal points), Climate-Smart Agriculture practices in Nepal (leading to provincial adoption and budget allocation), and heat resilience planning in South Asian cities. CDKN established ongoing platforms for knowledge exchange, including the Technical Table on Gender and Climate Change in Ecuador that brought together public actors, civil society, and researchers monthly, and created communities of practice that enhanced cross-sectoral coordination and mainstreaming of climate and gender considerations into national policies and programs.

outcomes.description: The project achieved sustained gender equality and inclusion transformations through multiple institutional and structural interventions. Women's representation in Wikipedia's climate editing community increased from 20% to 51% through edit-a-thons and capacity building, with 72% of editors from the global South. In Ethiopia, the Ministry of Women and Social Affairs became an active partner in climate action, a Community of Practice on gender and climate change was established across key ministries, and gender units were integrated into coordination mechanisms. Gender training resources developed by CDKN were widely adopted and institutionalized across multiple organizations including the UNFCCC Secretariat, UN Women Training Centre, and various government and NGO groups, with materials designed to explore climate risk through an intersectional lens and integrated into regional and national climate resilience planning in Nepal and Bangladesh.

outcomes.description: Across multiple regions, vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers were actively engaged in developing, co-creating, piloting, and testing climate innovations through CDKN-supported initiatives. In Nepal, LI-BIRD worked with municipalities, farming communities, cooperatives, and vulnerable women farmers through training and practical demonstrations to promote gender-responsive Climate-Smart Agriculture (CSA) technologies and practices, which were subsequently adopted by local governments and integrated into provincial policies and budgets. In Kenya and Uganda, over 4,000 smallholder farmers tested and adopted climate innovations including an SMS-based climate information tool for weather forecasts, hermetic storage bags for grain storage, and minimum tillage practices, resulting in increased crop resilience, reduced post-harvest losses (e.g., 43% increase in hermetic bag use), and improved market access and incomes. CDKN also significantly innovated in climate knowledge brokering methodologies themselves, developing new approaches that moved from knowledge translation to innovation brokering to facilitate systemic change in policy and practice, thereby creating a new framework for how climate innovations are developed and disseminated.
quotes: Throughout the project, LI-BIRD engaged with the municipalities, farming communities, cooperatives and vulnerable women farmers through training and practical demonstrations promoting gender-responsive CSA practices.

This suite of activities has benefited over 4,000 farmers who are members of the EAGC supported farmer G-hub (groups of farmers that farm similar areas and grains). Farmers have been able to increase the resilience of their crops, reduce post-harvest losses, and access better markets for their grains, all of which translate to improved incomes for smallholder farmers.

outcomes.description: The project produced a substantial body of research outputs and evidence on climate resilience and food systems, including four published papers in peer-reviewed journals with three additional manuscripts under preparation at project completion. These publications and research outputs addressed critical topics including uptake of agro-advisory services among farmers, adoption determinants and acceptability of climate smart agriculture practices, household socio-economic factors influencing dissemination pathways, policy effectiveness for climate adaptation, profitability of climate smart technologies, and climate change adaptation information's impact on food productivity in drylands. The research unpacked barriers and opportunities for farmers to utilize agro-advisory services and climate smart agriculture, contributing substantially to the literature and advancing the field of study. Additionally, the project supported capacity building through graduate student training, with four graduate students supported (two graduated and enrolled in PhD programs, one submitted their Masters thesis, and one was finalizing their thesis).
quotes: The project published four papers in peer reviewed journals and three more manuscripts are under preparation. Already available papers (listed in the section below) shed light on the uptake of agro-advisory services among farmers and the adoption and acceptability of climate smart agriculture practices, thereby contributing toward the literature in this area and moving this field of study forward.

Muriithi, L.N., et al. (2021). Adoption determinants of adapted climate smart agriculture technologies among smallholder farmers in Machakos, Makueni and Kitui counties of Kenya. Journal of Agricultural Extension, 25 (2):75-85.
Onyango, D., Mogaka, H., Ndirangu, S. and Kwena, K. (2022). Climate change adaptation information and food productivity in the drylands of Kenya: Counterfactual analysis.

outcomes.description: Smallholder farmers in Uganda and Kenya were actively involved in developing, testing, and adopting various climate and food system innovations through this project. In Uganda, farmers participated in testing and adopting climate smart agriculture practices including different planting dates, intercropping, fertilizer use, and varieties of maize and beans demonstrated in field sites, with the majority committing to adopt more than two of the demonstrated practices that showed higher profitability. In Kenya, farmers in the counties of Machakos, Makueni, and Kitui were involved in testing and using ICT-mediated climate information dissemination tools, including weather-based agro-advisories delivered through mobile phones and FM radio transmissions. Across both countries, farmers co-created and piloted these innovations, testing how the weather-based agro-advisories and agricultural advisories could help them make informed decisions, improve farming practices, and realize good yields even in marginal seasons.
quotes: In Uganda, most of the farmers in the implementation districts adopted weather-based advisories and adaptation options demonstrated in field sites. The project found that the different Climate Smart Agriculture practices including planting date, intercropping, fertilizer use and varieties of maize and beans were adopted by farmers and showed higher profitability.

In Kenya, the project directly contributed to the development of Climate Information Service Plans in three counties (Machakos, Makueni, and Kitui), leading to institutionalization and long-term financing of agro-advisory services for farmers. The project identified and successfully implemented institutional mechanisms for scaling climate adaptation services, creating a concrete model that can be applied in other countries on the continent. Additionally, the project examined enabling environments and policy frameworks needed for ICT-mediated climate information services to advise current climate policy and legislative processes in both Kenya and Uganda, contributing to IDRC's objective of informing practice by public and private sector actors.

outcomes.description: The project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on nutrition-sensitive agriculture, women's empowerment, and food systems in rural Ghana. Key research outputs included multiple peer-reviewed journal articles published in open access formats examining women's participation in Farmer-Based Organizations, maternal participation in nutrition-sensitive agriculture interventions, food security linkages to empowerment, and gender-based violence attitudes. Research findings generated critical baseline evidence (e.g., only 20-30% of women had bank accounts, 30-55% had income autonomy) and endline results demonstrating positive impacts on dietary diversity, food security, and empowerment through three nutrition-sensitive pathways (food production, income generation, and women's empowerment). Through extensive participatory testing and validation, smallholder farmers were directly involved in on-station and on-farm evaluations of 8 machines across four prioritized value chains (cassava, indigenous chicken, kales, and maize), with 38 on-farm demonstrations conducted involving 810 participants. outcomes.description: The project produced high-quality research evidence on digital solutions for nutrition and health data collection in Sub-Saharan Africa by developing and testing an ICT-based mobile application called Mbiotisho. Key research outputs included the development of a smartphone-accessible tool using audio and icon-based interfaces for illiterate populations, comprehensive gender dynamics research examining women's access to and control over mobile phones in low-literacy contexts (showing 94% access but only 53% control among women participants), accuracy and reliability testing that validated data collection methods through photo verification and reduced Technical Error of Measurement, and the production of multiple research publications, policy briefs, presentations, and a video documenting the innovation. The research demonstrated that with proper training, even illiterate caregivers could consistently collect high-frequency nutrition and health data, with 83% of 189 study participants submitting data at least twice monthly over 54 weeks, and opened opportunities for wider application including adaptations for drought surveillance, HIV monitoring, and child development tracking in collaboration with multiple international organizations.
quotes: Researchers developed a front-end mobile application designed to be user-friendly and operable, even by largely illiterate individuals, along with a back end-web system that serves as a database and dashboard for data analysis.

outcomes.description: The project successfully developed and tested Mbiotisho, an innovative ICT-based mobile application and web system for collecting real-time nutrition, dietary, and health data from vulnerable communities in Kenya. The innovation featured a user-friendly audio and icon-based interface designed to be operable even by largely illiterate individuals, using innovative methods including photos, interactive voice responses, and games for direct household data submission. The app was tested with 189 study participants over 54 weeks across several diverse communities, including pastoral communities in Marsabit District (Samburu and Rendille speakers), mothers of infants in informal settlements in Nairobi's Eastleigh neighborhood, and people living with HIV/AIDS. The innovation demonstrated high submission rates (83% of participants submitted data at least 27 weeks) and was successfully adapted for multiple applications beyond its primary focus, including drought surveillance, HIV monitoring, and child development tracking, with the versatility opening opportunities for collaboration with partners including the World Food Programme, NASCOP, Kilifi Department of Health, and Aga Khan University.
quotes: The mobile application was tested with several diverse communities in Kenya and results were closely monitored and validated through comparison of collected data with traditional methods and through engagement with other stakeholders in the nutrition sector.

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity to promote gender equality and inclusion through multiple approaches integrated into nutrition data collection efforts. The team developed and implemented strategies to address gender dynamics in technology use, carefully considering and addressing women's capacity to access and use digital data collection tools, including the Mbiotisho mobile application. A dedicated study on gender dynamics revealed critical insights about women's access to and control over smartphones, showing that while 94% of women participants had access to mobile phones, only 53% had control over their use, and that men still maintained control despite women's access. These findings informed the deployment strategy, leading to the involvement of both men and women in the project to avoid household conflicts. The gender-responsive approach developed through this project has now been institutionalized as a normal part of the organization's gender equality and inclusion framework, demonstrating sustained capacity strengthening beyond the project period.

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested a cost-effective smartphone-based application to improve the collection of high-resolution, individual-level, and near-time dietary, nutrition, and health data in Sub-Saharan Africa. This innovative tool provides an alternative to traditional field enumerator-based data collection approaches and helps close data gaps caused by seasonal changes. The application of this tool enables decision-makers to make data-driven agriculture, nutrition, and health policies and decisions to support nutrition-sensitive food and agriculture systems. The tool's versatility attracted multiple partner organizations during testing, leading to customization for various uses, including monitoring among mothers in informal settlements and tracking behavioral changes among people living with HIV/AIDS. Large-scale impact is anticipated through the tool's potential use in national surveys such as Demographic and Health Surveys conducted across 90 countries globally, including 44 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, with sample sizes of approximately 15,000 households per country.
quotes: The application of this tool will help to make data-driven agriculture, nutrition and health policies and decisions to support nutrition-sensitive food and agriculture systems.

outcomes.description: The Africa Food Systems Forum (formerly AGRF) significantly improved decision-makers' understanding of climate-related risks, food system transformation, and policy solutions through high-level convenings and knowledge-sharing platforms. The Forum brought together heads of state, ministers, government officials, private sector leaders, civil society, donors, and researchers to discuss and debate innovative approaches for agricultural productivity, food security, and building healthier, more inclusive, sustainable, and resilient food systems. IDRC's thought leadership and investment enabled scientists and researchers to present evidence directly to policy makers and food system stakeholders at main sessions and side events, influencing national, regional, and global development agendas. The Forum played a pivotal role in shaping African perspectives for global dialogues, including the UN Food Systems Summit 2021, where over 40 game-changing solutions were profiled and immediate actions for agricultural transformation were identified. IDRC's consistent advocacy elevated gender and youth issues in food systems discussions, bringing gendered evidence and women leaders to the forefront, resulting in increased awareness among all partners and stakeholders about the critical role of women and youth in food system transformation.
quotes: The Forum brings together current and former heads of state, ministers, civil society and private sector agencies, research communities, development partners, CEOs of global, regional and national business companies, grassroots organizations, farmers, youth representatives, and global thought leaders to discuss and debate innovative and practical ways to promote investments and policy support for increased agricultural productivity and income growth for African farmers, and more recently, for building healthier, more inclusive, sustainable, resilient, and equitable food systems.

outcomes.description: The project produced substantial new research evidence on climate change adaptation for vulnerable populations in Bangladesh's climate hotspots. Key research outputs included baseline studies and exploratory participatory research involving 2,700 households across six villages to understand differentiated impacts and vulnerability factors, and a national inventory on adaptation technologies in agriculture and water sectors that assessed appropriateness and effectiveness of these technologies. The project generated multiple peer-reviewed journal articles published in Disaster Prevention and Management and Environmental Hazards examining social learning, innovation, and community resilience to climate disasters, as well as a book chapter on empowering women through climate adaptation knowledge. Additionally, the research supported the completion of eight Masters-level theses and one PhD dissertation from universities in Bangladesh (Patuakhali Science and Technology University, Khulna University, Jahangirnagar University) and Canada (University of Manitoba), focusing on differentiated climate impacts, gender vulnerabilities, and agricultural adaptation technologies.

outcomes.description: The SAKTEE project involved vulnerable communities in developing, testing, and demonstrating climate adaptation technologies across water and agricultural sectors in two climate hotspots in Bangladesh. A national inventory on adaptation technologies in agriculture and water was prepared, assessing the appropriateness and effectiveness of these technologies through community consultations that identified commonly used agricultural practices and promising innovations. The project successfully facilitated household adoption of demonstrated technologies for drinking water and small agriculture, with technologies specifically designed to empower women and disadvantaged groups through multi-level institutional adoption and community participation.

project_name: Niger Delta

outcomes.description: The project generated extensive new knowledge on climate vulnerability, gender, and adaptation strategies in the Niger Delta region through comprehensive primary data collection including a baseline survey of 4,000 households, interviews with 107 key informants, 30 focus group discussions, and a COVID-19 impact assessment of 2,000 farmers. This research produced a substantial body of southern-based research outputs including 10 policy briefs, 5 peer-reviewed journal articles, 2 monographs, 2 Master's theses, training modules and guides, and research reports documenting drivers of climate vulnerability particularly affecting women farmers and their coping strategies. The knowledge produced filled critical gaps in understanding climate-related disasters in this highly fragile, hard-to-access region where rural communities, especially during periods of conflict and violence, have been understudied and existing research lacked adequate data. The research outputs documented gender-based assessments of climate adaptation strategies, economic vulnerability of households, COVID-19 impacts on food systems, and women's roles in climate resilience, all made available through open access publications that underwent rigorous external academic review.
quotes: New knowledge generated and documented from a highly fragile region on drivers of vulnerabilities and climate-change impacts on rural households, particularly on women farmers, and how they cope.

outcomes.description: Vulnerable women farmers in the Niger Delta region were engaged in developing, testing, and implementing climate and food system innovations through Community-based Project Implementation Committees (CPICs) established in 10 pilot communities across three ecological zones. A total of 250 women farmers (25 per community) were trained on multiple climate adaptation innovations including crop diversification/production, construction of flood control channels, different irrigation methods, fencing of ponds and fish traps, and land assessment techniques. Communities actively participated in identifying, selecting, and validating preparedness and adaptation strategies, with women leading the testing and implementation of community-based adaptation initiatives that included early maturing crops, pest-resistant varieties, flood control measures, and diversified farming practices. These pilot interventions were supported by local government agricultural inputs (fertilizers, improved seedlings, early maturing crops) and resulted in women farmers organizing into committees that became recognized channels for agricultural innovation dissemination and climate risk management.

outcomes.description: The project successfully mobilized additional financial resources from multiple sources that amplified the impact of climate resilience programming in Nigeria's Niger Delta region. Additionally, the Centre for Population and Environmental Development (CPED) secured a new grant from the United States Institute of Peace (USIP) for "Promoting Community-embedded youth peace building and conflict mitigation in Nigeria's Niger Delta region," with the capacity building received through this IDRC project—particularly around gender equality and feminist methodologies over 10 years of collaboration—hugely influencing the successful selection of this proposal. outcomes.description: More than 250 women farmers across 10 pilot communities in the Niger Delta region adopted climate resilience innovations and changed their agricultural practices to adapt to climate change. Through capacity building and training facilitated by Community-based Project Implementation Committees (CPICs), women farmers adopted multiple climate adaptation strategies including crop diversification, use of new seed varieties, early maturing crops (particularly maize), different irrigation methods, early planting, crop rotation, minimum tillage, and pest-resistant varieties. Women organized themselves into committees and networks that became recognized by local government authorities, who now use these networks as channels to distribute subsidized farm inputs. The adoption of these innovations has enabled farming households to spread risk over a wider range of crops, reduce vulnerability to extreme weather events, increase produce quantities, and improve food security and household incomes.

outcomes.description: Women's committees and networks were created and gained formal recognition from local government units, becoming the voice for women in 10 pilot communities and advocating for women's inclusion in decision-making and land ownership rights beyond climate change issues. Structural changes in gender equality were achieved, with women gaining decision-making positions in community committees—notably in Uzere community where 5 women joined an 11-member Community Development Committee (CDC) with 2 in leadership positions by January 2022. outcomes.description: The project generated extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience in the highly fragile and data-scarce Congo River Basin region of northeastern DRC. Knowledge production covered hydro-climatic indices as drivers of conflicts and migration (1960-2018 and projections to 2100), gender analysis of climate-water-migration-conflict interactions across 13 thematic areas, and mixed effects of conflict and migration in sociocultural contexts. The project produced comprehensive outputs including one book, one scientific gender analysis report, six peer-reviewed articles, five master's theses, two conference articles, eight policy briefs, one open access integrated information system database with 575 disaggregated variables, one virtual course, and a photo story album for research monitoring. Research was based on data from 1,008 individuals surveyed across 150 households per province from five sociolinguistic groups, utilizing mixed methods including household surveys, focus groups, semi-structured interviews, meteorological stations, geospatial data, and space observations.

outcomes.description: The project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research on climate resilience, gender, and migration through an interdisciplinary approach involving five academic units at Universidad Nacional de San Martín (UNSAM). outcomes.description: This project produced substantial high-quality, southern-based research evidence on food environments and non-communicable diseases in Ghana, exceeding its targets by generating 7 peer-reviewed publications and 3 policy briefs that are contributing to shaping Ghana's food policies. The research represented the first study of its kind in West Africa documenting the nature and extent of unhealthy food and beverage promotion across multiple platforms including television, billboards, and retail outlets, and assessed the comprehensiveness of Ghana's School Feeding Policy and Programme using global benchmarking tools. The project established Africa's first Food Environment Research Network (FERN), convening African researchers to share experiences on improving food environments, with the first two meetings attracting approximately 160 and 100 attendees respectively from around the world. The knowledge generated received extensive media coverage (over two dozen media articles) and led to invitations to present findings at key policy forums including stakeholder consultative meetings convened by Ghana's Ministry of Health and the International Strategic Dialogue on NCDs and SDGs.
quotes: This project resulted in 7 peer reviewed publications (exceeding its target of 6 publications) and 3 policy briefs (exceeding its target of 2 policy briefs). Additionally, the project was covered or mentioned by over two dozen media articles. Overall, the body of knowledge generated by this project is contributing to shaping Ghana's food policies.

outcomes.description: The project generated new knowledge and evidence that improved decision-makers' understanding of food system issues and policy solutions in Ghana, resulting in 7 peer-reviewed publications and 3 policy briefs that exceeded targets. Ghana's Ministry of Health invited the project team to present findings at a stakeholders consultative meeting to develop a food policy bundle to address rising diet-related non-communicable diseases, demonstrating direct uptake of the evidence by government decision-makers. The policy briefs and research outputs provided specific recommendations on restricting unhealthy food marketing to children, implementing nutrition standards in school feeding programs, and limiting children's exposure to unhealthy food and beverage advertisements on television and billboards near schools. The evidence showed that 58% of food advertisements on national television and 70% of billboard ads near schools promoted unhealthy products, and that Ghana's School Feeding Policy and Programme lacked comprehensive nutrition standards and enforcement mechanisms, providing decision-makers with concrete data to inform policy reforms.

outcomes.description: The project generated substantial evidence that directly informed policy development in Ghana to address diet-related non-communicable diseases and improve children's food environments. The project team was invited by Ghana's Ministry of Health to present findings at a stakeholders consultative meeting convened to develop a food policy bundle to assure healthier diets amidst rising diet-related NCDs. The project produced 3 policy briefs (exceeding its target of 2) offering concrete recommendations for policymakers on restricting marketing of unhealthy foods to children, improving nutritional quality of sold and provided foods in Ghanaian schools, and addressing food availability around schools. Based on research findings showing that 58% of food advertisements on national television and 70% of billboard advertisements near schools promoted unhealthy products, the project team recommended that the Government of Ghana implement policies limiting children's exposure to unhealthy food and beverages, including restrictions on TV advertisements during peak viewing times for children, regulations for billboard placement near schools, and establishment of comprehensive food-based and nutrient-based standards for the Ghana School Feeding Policy and Programme.

outcomes.description: The research team applied and tested the Community Readiness Mapping (CRM) tool in the Accra region of Ghana to assess community readiness for interventions addressing children's food environments. The CRM tool comprises 36 open-ended questions covering five readiness dimensions: community awareness of initiatives, leadership, community environment, community understanding of the issue, and resources. The assessment revealed that the Accra region is at the Pre-Planning stage (overall readiness score of 4 out of 9), indicating that while efforts are underway to address marketing and availability of unhealthy food and drinks near schools, community members recognize that more action needs to be taken. This testing of the CRM framework represents the application of an innovative assessment tool in a vulnerable community context to inform future interventions for improving children's food environments and preventing obesity and non-communicable diseases.

outcomes.description: The project produced multiple high-quality research outputs contributing to knowledge on climate-resilient food systems and nutrition in the Andean region. This included publishing one of the first peer-reviewed papers on COVID-19's impact on food security of agricultural communities in South America, which raised government awareness of the need for specific policies to support farming communities. The project generated several journal articles on potato farming, biofortification, and food systems challenges in the Andean context; technical reports and project profiles; conference presentations; and audio-visual materials including a video and song promoting biofortified potatoes that were subsequently adopted by government agencies for use in other rural areas. The project also contributed to evaluating eight biofortified potato clones for two consecutive years to support the release of new enriched varieties, adapted research methodologies including the FAO KAP-Anemia survey and RTB Scaling Readiness methodology for the Peruvian context, and produced evidence showing that biofortified potatoes can significantly improve iron and zinc absorption to help address anemia in vulnerable populations.
