outcomes.description: The FASIMO project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience and sustainable food systems in Mozambique's smallholder irrigation sector. Key research outputs included: cost-effective GIS models and remote sensing algorithms for identifying and mapping irrigated areas using Digital Earth Africa platform; comprehensive gender analysis using Pro-WEAI modules that documented women's empowerment domains, workload imbalances, and access to irrigation resources; evidence on factors influencing success and failure of irrigation schemes including management techniques, institutional arrangements, and business models; and documented models for improving irrigation performance that incorporate participatory approaches, transparent governance structures, and agricultural technologies. Research outputs were disseminated through multiple channels including policy briefs, technical papers, case studies, blogs, videos, and stakeholder workshops, with findings informing evidence-based interventions and being adopted by government institutions (INIR) and other development projects (IRRIGA, WaPOR, APSAN VALE, TISA).

outcomes.description: The project successfully developed, adapted, and tested multiple Integrated Pest Management (IPM) innovations with vulnerable communities including mango growers and resource-poor farmers across four Southern African countries. Over 4,000 farmers (62% women) were trained as trainers on IPM techniques (mass trapping using lures, protein baits, sanitation, biological pesticides, and parasitoids) and all received IPM starter packs and used the technologies throughout implementation. The project also developed and tested innovative solutions including host marking pheromones (glutathione and glutamic acid), simple basket dryers made of polyethylene nets for mango preservation that allowed women to earn 8 times more than selling fresh fruit, and biological control methods using parasitoids that established in mango farms. An additional 11,131 farmers (47% women) were reached through farmer field days to demonstrate and test technologies, with participatory monitoring groups involving farmers in decision-making, while the project also tested and refined temperature thresholds for parasitoid releases and conducted modeling for parasitoid establishment areas.

outcomes.description: Over 4,000 mango growers (62% women) were trained and adopted Integrated Pest Management (IPM) technologies—including mass trapping, protein baits, sanitation, and biological pesticides—throughout the project implementation cycle, shifting from conventional synthetic insecticides to sustainable pest management practices. An additional 11,131 farmers (47% women) were reached through farmer field days and trained to use IPM technologies, reducing crop losses from fruit fly infestation from 80% to 30% and increasing household annual income from mango crops by 7-18% in Zambia. Women farmers specifically adopted solar drying techniques using simple basket dryers made of polyethylene nets to reduce post-harvest losses, with dried mangoes selling for 8 times more than fresh fruit in Zambia and Zimbabwe. Farmers also adopted additional innovations based on research findings, including grafting improved mango varieties using indigenous drought-resistant trees as rootstock. These practice changes improved food and nutrition security, provided income generation opportunities, and reduced poverty while lowering women's workload and contributing to women's empowerment through savings groups and revolving credit cooperatives.

outcomes.description: The project achieved sustained transformational changes in gender equality and women's empowerment across multiple dimensions. Women experienced measurable empowerment gains, including a 6% increase in Zambia, driven by reduced workload through IPM technologies (traps requiring attention only every 4-6 weeks versus carrying chemical sprayers), increased income from solar drying techniques (dried mangoes selling 8 times more than fresh fruit in Zambia and Zimbabwe), and enhanced access to agricultural extension services tailored for inclusivity. outcomes.description: The project produced comprehensive high-quality research and evidence on climate-resilient and sustainable food systems in Uganda's fisheries sector. Multiple peer-reviewed publications were produced addressing food security inequities, fishery management, nutritional security, and women's empowerment, along with practical outputs including five certified fish-enriched products, a 16-recipe small fishes cookbook endorsed by the Minister of State for Fisheries, and documented learnings on proper planning and appropriate tool introduction to guide future IDRC programs.

The fellows produced substantial knowledge products including journal publications (with 1 published article and 12 additional manuscripts in development from one fellow alone), conference presentations, databases of whole genome sequences, professional development materials, and research findings on topics including bovine mastitis control in Brazil, Salmonella vaccines for Kenyan poultry, coronavirus surveillance in non-human primates in Kenya, and other veterinary pathogens in Egypt, India, and South Africa. outcomes.description: Vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers across three African countries were actively involved in developing, co-creating, piloting, and testing multiple climate and food system innovations. outcomes.description: The project produced high-quality, Southern-based research outputs that synthesized CARIAA learning and advanced knowledge on climate resilience and food systems across three key thematic areas. Major research contributions included: peer-reviewed publications on the "triple vulnerability" framework for female entrepreneurs to climate risk in sub-Saharan Africa (published in WIRES Climate Change), studies on perceived environmental risks and migration intentions in hazardous coastal areas (published in One Earth), research on climate mobilities and urban migrant well-being, and elaboration of the climate resilient development pathways concept that was incorporated into the latest IPCC Assessment Report. These outputs represented valuable synthesis of previously funded research, bringing together insights and evidence across multiple studies in ways that enhanced understanding of the climate-food systems nexus, migration patterns, gender dimensions of adaptation, and human security. The research outputs went beyond academic quality to provide meaningful knowledge synthesis across systematic literature reviews, empirical studies, and conceptual advances that inform climate change adaptation policy and practice.

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity to promote gender equality and inclusion in climate adaptation through the development of a framework on the "triple differential vulnerability" of female entrepreneurs to climate risk in sub-Saharan Africa. This conceptual advance identified gendered barriers and enablers to private sector adaptation, recognizing that women entrepreneurs face higher sensitivity to climate risks due to their concentration in certain sectors, encounter additional barriers to adaptation (including access to finance, technologies, climate information, and supportive policies), and simultaneously manage climate risk at household levels. The project's findings and recommendations informed policy actors including Kenya's National Drought Management Authority to improve small business opportunities for women, particularly proposing Village Saving and Loan Associations to facilitate access to sustainable financial resources. These capacity-building outcomes advanced understanding of the role of gender in adaptation efforts and provided tools and approaches for integrating gender equality considerations into climate adaptation and food system policies and practices.

The project recommended using Village Saving and Loan Associations to facilitate local fundraising, with the expected outcome that more women will have access to sustainable financial resources to help build resilient businesses and improve livelihoods and well-being. Additionally, the project produced a conceptual advance on the "triple differential vulnerability" of female entrepreneurs to climate change in sub-Saharan Africa, identifying gendered barriers and enablers to private sector adaptation including access to finance, technologies, climate information, and supportive policies.

outcomes.description: This project generated substantial high-quality research and evidence on climate resilience, forest conservation, and sustainable food systems across multiple African countries. Key knowledge products included: new analysis of climate impacts on cocoa production in Ghana combining over 70 years of government and company data to assess El Niño event impacts on harvests, revealing approximately 20% lower cocoa yields during El Niño years; research on wood fuel and charcoal industry in Mozambique using state-of-the-art remote sensing, informing local government management of this industry that represents 5% of GDP and employs over 5% of the population; analysis of forest fire drivers in Madagascar that informed policy reforms; and blue carbon research in Kenya that informed updates to Nationally Determined Contributions including payment for ecosystem services. outcomes.description: This project produced high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on fiscal policy interventions for non-communicable disease (NCD) prevention in Kenya, representing one of the first studies of its kind in Eastern Africa. Key research outputs included an Excel-based simulation model for assessing the impact of sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) taxes on obesity prevalence in Kenya (the first such simulation in the country and adaptable to other countries), a published working paper on fiscal and public health effects of SSB taxation, and two draft manuscripts on ultra-processed foods taxation and consumption patterns. The research generated specific evidence-based findings including that ultra-processed foods account for 12% of dietary intake in urban Kenyan households, that an SSB tax could reduce consumption by 20% and increase government revenue by 140%, and that such taxation could modestly reduce overweight and obesity prevalence. This knowledge production positioned the project team and their institutions as leading voices on fiscal policy for NCD prevention in Sub-Saharan Africa and provided evidence to inform policymakers on health-promoting tax reforms.

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested an innovative SSB (sugar-sweetened beverage) tax simulation model as a policy tool to address food system challenges and non-communicable diseases in Kenya. The model analyzed data from four nationally representative datasets (including the 2005 and 2015 Kenya Integrated Household Budget Surveys, Tegemeo Institute 2015 rural household study, and 2012 urban food consumption survey) to project that a tax of 0.3 KES per gram would decrease per capita SSB consumption by 20%, reduce overweightness prevalence among males from 20% to 18% and females from 32% to 30%, and reduce obesity prevalence among males from 3.1% to 2.7% and females from 8.4% to 7.4%. The model also projected that excise tax revenue would increase by 140% (from 11 billion KES to 33 billion KES) if implemented. This represents one of the first evidence-based fiscal policy tools of its kind in Eastern Africa for NCD prevention, positioning the research team as leading voices on fiscal policy for NCD prevention in Sub-Saharan Africa.

project_name: CLARE1 scoping-design-transition

outcomes.description: The CLARE1 partnership established and strengthened an equitable collaboration between IDRC and UK DFID/FCDO through innovative team-to-team engagement, co-authorship of the research framework business case, and shared responsibilities that positioned IDRC as an equal partner rather than a service provider. This partnership model evolved from previous one-to-one relationships to broader collaborative structures where IDRC staff paired with FCDO Research Advisors, jointly prepared annual reviews, and made intellectual contributions to program design. The partnership also catalyzed the formation of the Adaptation Research Alliance, a global coalition that grew six-fold from 30 to 190 members spanning research-performing, funding, practice-, and community-based organizations committed to action-oriented research. The CLARE framework prioritized equitable partnerships as a core principle, encouraging diverse coalitions with shared participation, mutual accountability, and balanced roles for southern actors in research design, implementation, and uptake.
quotes: The Climate and Resilience transition fund (or 'CLARE1') is a partnership between IDRC and the UK Department for International Development. It represented a joint investment of CA$7.1 million aimed at scaling, uptake, and impact of climate research, as well as designing the next generation of research needed to accelerate adaptation and catalyze climate action in the Global South.
Since 2021, the Alliance grew six-fold (from 30 to 190 members) spanning research-performing, -funding, practice-, and community-based organizations committed to action-oriented research.

CLARE1 allowed IDRC to champion new ways of working with DFID (later FCDO) by coauthoring business case and sharing responsibilities through team-to-team collaboration. Whereas previous partnerships concentrated on the one-to-one relationship between PL to SRO, CLARE1 experimented with pairing IDRC Program Officers with FCDO Research Advisors to work together.
Through its contributions 2019-2021, IDRC demonstrated its ability and earned a more substantial role in CLARE2 than had been initial hoped for.

outcomes.description: The project generated comprehensive evidence and research outputs supporting the Climate Smart Villages (CSV) model as a platform for implementing climate-smart agriculture (CSA) practices toward resilience, women's empowerment, equity, and sustainable food systems. Key research outputs included development of the Household Resilience Score (HRS) methodology to measure resilience in CSA contexts, investigations into women's economic empowerment pathways, cost-benefit analyses of climate-smart practices across diverse agro-ecological locations, documentation of social learning methods for CSA diffusion, and assessments of community-based social protection mechanisms like village savings groups. The project filled critical data gaps on costs (direct and indirect) and benefits (economic, ecological, and social) of various climate-smart practices, producing multiple open-access publications including meta-analyses, research briefs, assessments of local food systems, and COVID-19 rapid assessments. Evidence from participatory action research across six CSV sites in three countries demonstrated that the CSV approach contributed to climate change adaptation, household resilience, women's economic empowerment, social inclusion, and food security, with findings positioned to influence regional investments including by the ASEAN secretariat.

outcomes.description: The project successfully involved vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers across Philippines, Cambodia, and Myanmar in developing, testing, and adopting climate-smart agriculture (CSA) innovations through the Climate Smart Villages (CSV) platform. Farmers used participatory action research methods and social learning approaches to identify, test, and improve climate adaptation options from a portfolio of proven technologies, including stress-tolerant crop varieties, homestead vegetable gardens, small livestock integration, agroforestry systems, green manure application, and tree-based farming systems. The project developed and tested the Household Resilience Score (HRS) methodology as a tool to monitor household resilience outcomes from climate change interventions. Through demonstration sites and observation of early adopters' success, late adopters were motivated to test and adopt these innovations, triggering increased uptake of CSA technologies. Cost-benefit analysis demonstrated the financial viability of the CSV model, with participating households collectively generating net benefits ranging from USD 44,640 to USD 76,344 per year in Myanmar's Climate Smart Villages, while the innovations also provided social benefits including economic empowerment, food security, and gender responsiveness.
quotes: In the context of CSVs, these participatory methods are important because they helped nurture the capacities of farmers to identify, test and improve climate adaptation options from a portfolio of proven technologies shared by the project team.

outcomes.description: The project generated substantial evidence and insights that improved understanding of climate-smart agriculture (CSA) and climate-smart villages (CSV) as effective platforms for building resilience, women's empowerment, and sustainable food systems. Key findings included the development and validation of the Household Resilience Score (HRS) methodology for monitoring household resilience; documentation of cost-benefit data showing financial viability of CSV models; evidence of social learning methods' effectiveness for diffusion of CSA techniques; insights into women's economic empowerment alongside continued wage inequalities; and assessment of COVID-19 impacts on local agri-food systems revealing CSV resilience through homestead gardens and small livestock. These research outputs and evidence were disseminated through multiple publications, a Regional Learning Conference, and engagement with stakeholders including ASEAN secretariat, World Food Programme, and other development partners, positioning findings to influence regional investments and policy decisions.
quotes: Analysis of data also indicated that HRS can be a feasible methodology to monitor or track household resilience as an outcome of climate change-related interventions.
COVID-19 impact on local agri-food system in Cambodia, Myanmar, and the Philippines: Findings from a rapid assessment.

The capacity building activities integrated into the project helped communities, partners, and stakeholders to understand and support the long-term viability of CSVs and CSA, preparing them to better respond to the impacts of negative climate events. Information generated is well-positioned to influence investments in the region including, for example, by the ASEAN secretariat which is active in promoting CSA.

The extension also permitted the project to organize a Regional Learning Conference and Workshop in Philippines where research data on the uptake of CSV lessons were disseminated to the target 'next users,' or stakeholders who can serve as vehicles for scaling out and up for a potentially wider project reach.
outcomes.geography: Philippines, Cambodia, Myanmar, South East Asia

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity across multiple actors to promote gender equality and inclusion through evidence generation, research outputs, and development of inclusive climate-smart agriculture approaches. Key achievements included: (1) generating evidence on CSA's contribution to women's economic empowerment, revealing increased income levels, enhanced participation in joint decision-making on production and household expenditures, and more active engagement in trainings and community activities, while also identifying persistent challenges like wage inequality and women's time poverty; (2) producing targeted research outputs including studies on pathways to women's empowerment, gender outcomes harvesting meta-analysis, and social inclusion evaluations that provide tools and knowledge for integrating gender equality into climate adaptation policies; and (3) developing and demonstrating socially inclusive CSA options that specifically considered women-headed households with limited land, supported by participatory approaches including community support funds that incentivized participation of both men and women farmers in research activities. The project built capacity of communities, partners, and stakeholders to understand and support gender-responsive climate-smart agriculture, positioning findings to influence regional investments including through the ASEAN secretariat.
quotes: Findings indicate the contribution of CSA to women's economic empowerment through increased levels of income which they contribute to the household, increased participation in joint decision-making on production and major household expenditures, and more active participation of women in trainings and community activities.

outcomes.description: The Climate Smart Villages (CSV) project successfully demonstrated the adoption of climate-smart agriculture (CSA) practices by farmers across multiple sites through social learning methods, where late adopters were convinced to test interventions after witnessing beneficial impacts on early adopters. A menu of socially inclusive climate-smart agriculture options—including stress-tolerant crop varieties, homestead vegetable gardens, small livestock production, fruit-tree-based agroforestry, and improved soil health practices—were tested in various agro-climatic contexts and made ready for adoption by local communities, NGOs, and government entities. The project established demonstration sites that attracted additional farmers to join after the benefits became evident, supported by community-level incentives and a favorable cost-benefit analysis that showed households benefited financially from adopting the interventions. The adopted practices demonstrated resilience during COVID-19 lockdowns, with homestead gardens and small livestock buffering negative impacts by providing food security and enabling households to share or sell vegetables to neighbors. The project approach proved viable as a local platform for building resilience, women's empowerment, social inclusion, and food security, with evidence positioned to influence regional investments including by the ASEAN secretariat.
quotes: When participating farmers in the CSVs identified and tested a menu of adaptation options, it triggered an increase in the number of adopters of the technologies. Late adopters were convinced to test the interventions because they had witnessed for themselves the beneficial impacts on the early adopters.

This menu of options tested in a range of agro-climatic contexts of the participating communities in three countries which support household resilience, inclusiveness, and sustainable food systems were ready for adoption by local communities, NGOs, and government.
The project demonstrated the feasibility and importance of social learning methods for farmers (i.e. learning through observation of other people's behaviour) for the diffusion of CSA techniques.

outcomes.target_population: Smallholder farmers in Climate Smart Villages including both early and late adopters; women farmers and women-headed households; men and women farmers participating in CSV research activities; local communities, NGOs, and government entities; households with varying land areas (large land areas, homesteads, limited land areas); climate adaptation and food system actors

outcomes.outcome_type: Sustained Gender Equality and Inclusion Transformations
outcomes.description: The Climate Smart Villages (CSV) project generated evidence demonstrating sustained transformations in gender equality and social inclusion through multiple pathways. The project contributed to women's economic empowerment by increasing women's income levels contributed to households, enhancing their participation in joint decision-making on production and major household expenditures, and fostering more active engagement in trainings and community activities. Women participating in CSV activities became more engaged with male counterparts in decision-making related to small livestock (goats, pigs, chickens) due to gained experience and knowledge through interventions. The CSV approach was specifically designed with socially inclusive options adaptable to different contexts including women-headed households, households with limited land, and homesteads, supporting not only women's economic empowerment but also social inclusion more broadly. However, the research also documented persistent structural inequalities, including continued wage gaps (women earning 30% less than men farmers) and time poverty with women spending an average of 15.2 hours per day on economic activities and housework.
quotes: Findings indicate the contribution of CSA to women's economic empowerment through increased levels of income which they contribute to the household, increased participation in joint decision-making on production and major household expenditures, and more active participation of women in trainings and community activities.

Evidence generated as a result of the project revealed that the CSV approach has contributed to supporting climate change adaptation in agriculture, household resilience, women's economic empowerment, social inclusion, and food security.
outcomes.geography: Philippines, Cambodia, Myanmar, South East Asia
outcomes.target_population: Smallholder farmers in climate smart villages, women farmers, women-headed households, households with limited land areas, men and women participating in CSV activities, community members in six CSV sites across three countries

outcomes.description: The project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience and healthy, sustainable food systems in Latin America. A multidisciplinary coalition of researchers across three countries conducted comprehensive literature reviews, policy reviews, political economy analyses, and stakeholder analyses that consolidated evidence on accelerating transitions to healthy, sustainable food systems while keeping GHG emissions within sustainable limits. Key research outputs included three national technical reports, the "Five Dimensions of the Food System" study, national agendas for action in each country, political manifestos, policy briefs, and brochures that informed understanding of governance challenges, knowledge gaps, and policy gaps in food systems. The project significantly expanded the field of research and action in the LAC region by bridging the previously disconnected domains of public health nutrition, climate change, and sustainable agriculture, establishing a novel integrated evidence base focused on the interface between healthy, environmental, and climate-friendly food systems.

outcomes.description: The project produced multiple high-quality research outputs and evidence on climate-resilient food systems across three African countries. outcomes.description: The project produced comprehensive high-quality, southern-based research outputs on shea parklands and value chains in Burkina Faso, totaling 27 research outputs including 4 successfully completed and defended MSc theses, multiple peer-reviewed journal articles, CIFOR key reports, policy briefs, and presentations at international forums including the World Summit on Food Systems. The research generated new knowledge on climate resilience, food system shocks (insecurity and COVID-19), gender dimensions of shea production, and sustainable parkland management, with all outputs produced in English and French, and key syntheses translated to Bobo and Mossi languages. Lead authorship was retained by local southern scientists from institutions including Université Nazi Boni and INERA Burkina Faso, with primary data control maintained locally. The research directly informed evidence-based policy recommendations and contributed to the development of participatory action plans for inclusive shea park management in two communes, an independent review of the National Strategy for Sustainable Development of the Shea Sector, and co-production of a guidance document with national ministries that serves as the knowledge basis for improved governance of shea parklands and value chains.
quotes: The key results generated by this project were: 1) A complete report on the status of shea parklands in Burkina Faso, of the women's groups managing them, of the current legislation gaps and opportunities; and 2) a guidance document – co-produced with the ministries of Environments and of Agriculture of Burkina Faso

outcomes.outcome_type: Improved Understanding of Climate and Food System Issues and Policy Solutions
outcomes.description: Government decision-makers in Burkina Faso gained improved understanding of policy solutions for shea parklands management and climate resilience, particularly through a guidance document co-produced with the Ministries of Environment and Agriculture that now serves as the knowledge basis for improved governance and management of shea parklands and shea value chains to reduce women's vulnerabilities to economic and climate shocks. The National Shea Forum (June 24-25, 2021) attended by 180 representatives resulted in a "Call to Action" that positioned shea within the Ministry of Environment, Green Economy and Climate Change (MEEVCC) portfolio and led to shea parklands being placed under joint supervision of the Ministry of Agriculture and MEEVCC for the first time. Decision-makers gained enhanced understanding of climate-related risks, the differential impacts of insecurity and COVID-19 on various value chain stakeholders, vulnerabilities of women producers, and policy solutions including parkland restoration programs, genetic development of shea trees, potential export taxes, and strategies for sustainable food systems. The project's evidence-based recommendations and research findings were presented at high-level forums including the World Summit on Food Systems and Regional Shea Alliance meetings, and informed the co-drafting of a new national strategy for valorization of shea parklands with actionable policy guidance for government agencies, shea producer associations, and transnational corporations.
quotes: a guidance document – co-produced with the ministries of Environments and of Agriculture of Burkina Faso – that is now used by the national government to be the knowledge basis for the improved governance and management of shea parklands and shea value chains to reduce the vulnerabilities of women to economic and climate shocks

The outcome of the National Shea Forum was an important policy shift to guide the future restoration and management of agroforestry parklands, which will support the overall objective of the 'Globalizations in a Nutshell' research project by improving the resilience of the parklands and women shea butter producers.

outcomes.description: The project achieved significant policy adoption and implementation in Burkina Faso to promote sustainable and inclusive management of shea parklands and value chains. Key outcomes included: (1) a guidance document co-produced with the Ministries of Environment and Agriculture that is now used by the national government as the knowledge basis for improved governance and management of shea parklands to reduce women's vulnerabilities to economic and climate shocks; (2) for the first time in Burkina Faso, shea parklands were placed under joint supervision of the Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of Environment, with shea being reclassified as an agricultural crop rather than a tree to ensure better protection; (3) a National Shea Forum (June 2021) with 180 stakeholders resulted in a 'Call to Action' positioning shea within the Ministry of Environment's portfolio and aligning with Burkina Faso's National Climate Change Adaptation Plan and Second National Shea Development Strategy 2021-2025; (4) the project participated in developing participatory action plans for inclusive shea parkland management in two communes (Sapouy and Bougnounou-Nébiélianayou) and reviewed the national shea sector strategy; and (5) a new national strategy inclusive of women in the shea value chain was developed, with women gaining stronger presence in the national coordination body (Table de Concertation sur la Filière de Karité).

outcomes.description: The AgMIP A-Teams project produced substantial high-quality, southern-based research outputs on climate resilience and food systems, including more than 35 published outputs with approximately 15 peer-reviewed articles, and 5 African chapters of the AgMIP Handbook on Climate Change and Agroecosystems. The project developed sophisticated modeling and scenarios building efforts, including Regional Integrated Assessments (RIA) and Representative Agricultural Pathways (RAP), which are co-produced with national stakeholders and fill a critical "missing middle" gap by operating at the national scale rather than only regional or local levels. Key research tools were developed and adapted for three national contexts, including the "Impact Explorer" decision support tool, and refinements to standard modeling tools such as DSSAT, InfoCrop and CropMaker that are now considered state-of-the-art in the climate and agricultural modeling field. The research produced important findings such as quantified impacts showing that a 4°C temperature increase by 2081-2100 could result in maize yield decreases of 14-26% in sub-Saharan Africa, and developed unique protocols linking climate, crop production, and economic models to identify promising areas for investment in climate-resilient value chains and food security.
quotes: The very sophisticated and detailed modeling and scenarios building efforts led by AgMIP, and in particular the Regional Integrated Assessments and the Representative Agricultural Pathways building exercises, are innovative because they are co-produced with national stakeholders

This project also contributed to generate knowledge and solutions for large scale positive change, as the decision support tools developed by AgMIP are considered state-of-the-art in the climate and agricultural modelling field, and widely used in the research community.

outcomes.description: The AgMIP A-Teams project developed and tested the Impact Explorer (IE) decision support tool, adapting it to three national contexts (Ghana, Senegal, and Zimbabwe) for application in informing National Adaptation Plans (NAPs) implementation and conducting agricultural impact assessments. The project involved vulnerable countries and national stakeholders in co-producing sophisticated modeling tools and scenario-building exercises, including Regional Integrated Assessments and Representative Agricultural Pathways, which were adapted to a broader variety of agroecological zones and can now be used at the national scale. Southern partners actively used the AgMIP tools and methodologies in real-world applications beyond the project, including assessing COVID-19 response measures' effectiveness on food systems in Senegal's Niayes region and informing agroecological transition planning in West Africa. The project also contributed to refining standard modeling tools used by the international research community (DSSAT, InfoCrop, and CropMaker) and filled a "missing middle" gap in modeling between regional and local scales. These innovations are now being used to inform multilateral and bilateral funding priorities, agricultural development plans, and proposals to the Green Climate Fund.

outcomes.description: Decision-makers across Ghana, Senegal, and Zimbabwe gained improved understanding of climate-related risks, agricultural development trade-offs, and adaptation policy solutions through AgMIP's research and tools. The project provided clarity on trade-offs between agricultural development scenarios and poverty reduction, investment choices in crops and livestock, and debunked myths about GHG emissions reduction strategies through cattle reduction. Government ministries, environmental agencies, and national institutions requested training and began using AgMIP's Impact Explorer tool as a diagnostic instrument for policy discussions, including for National Adaptation Plans (NAPs), food sovereignty assessments, and agroecological transition planning. The research also informed international stakeholders including USAID and the Green Climate Fund on adaptation priorities, with findings such as projected maize yield declines of 14-26% by 2081-2100 with 4°C temperature rise speaking to food sovereignty risks. AgMIP methodologies were incorporated into Green Climate Fund proposals and civil society platforms, with tools being used in COVID-19 response planning and food value chain upgrading discussions.

outcomes.description: This project generated substantial high-quality research outputs and evidence on climate resilience and sustainable food systems across South Asia. The research produced at least 8 peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals (including articles in Progress in Disaster Science, Science of Total Environment, Scientific Data, and Environmental Science and Policy), with one article on Climate Resilient Development Pathways being cited in the IPCC 6th Assessment Report. Additional outputs included 4 post-graduate theses, 3 policy briefs covering climate risk reduction and adaptation effectiveness, multiple technical reports (including evaluation of heat stress warning systems), and blog posts on COVID-19 impacts on heat stress and livelihoods. Key research contributions included: refinement of the Dynamic Adaptation Model as an open-source desktop application; field survey data from 1,500 households providing evidence on lived experiences of adaptation to four hazards; novel indoor heat measurement data from low-income households; and empirical evidence on Climate Resilient Development Pathways examining scaling potential of four livelihood innovations in the Hindu Kush Himalaya region.

outcomes.description: The project developed, piloted, and tested multiple climate and food system innovations across South Asia involving vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers. In Bangladesh, the team mapped outcomes and tested the effectiveness of four livelihood innovations from CARIAA (flood-resistant housing, climate-smart agriculture, springshed restoration, and solar-powered irrigation pumps), examining opportunities for scaling and identifying barriers such as cost constraints and gender dynamics. In India, a novel rural heat advisory system was piloted, disseminating three-day heat stress forecasts via mobile text message to over 2,000 farmers across 20 villages in Maharashtra, with information tailored to individual farmers and their livelihood activities based on local automated weather stations. The project also tested temperature data loggers and indoor heat measurement systems to better understand differential exposure to heat stress in low-income households. These innovations advanced climate services delivery, adaptation technologies, and heat-health warning systems through co-creation and testing with farming communities and vulnerable populations across the Hindu Kush Himalayan region.

outcomes.description: The research team successfully produced and characterized innovative vaccine platforms including nanorings and nanofilaments decorated with conserved epitopes (M2e and HA2) of influenza A viruses for potential universal protection against avian influenza. The project generated substantial knowledge outputs including one registered patent and multiple peer-reviewed scientific articles published in high-impact journals (including Frontiers in Immunology, Biomaterials, and Nanomaterials) covering vaccine development, nanoplatform design, adjuvant testing, and respiratory pathogens. Through extensive experimental work, the team produced research evidence on the immunogenicity and protective potential of various vaccine constructions, testing multiple nanoring and nanofilament configurations with three different adjuvants in mice and chickens, demonstrating that combination vaccines with M2e and full HA protein achieved 100% protection against heterologous H5N1 infection compared to 66% mortality with HA alone. Despite the ultimate vaccine formulation not meeting all intended objectives, the project contributed valuable scientific knowledge about vaccination strategies using recombinant nanoplatforms and synthetic peptides, addressing critical challenges in poultry health systems and informing future research directions in vaccine development for highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses.

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested innovative next-generation avian influenza vaccine approaches using novel nanotechnology-based formulations, including nanorings, nanofilaments, and self-assembled nanorod platforms. Multiple vaccine constructions were produced and tested through vaccination trials and experimental challenges in both mouse and chicken models, targeting conserved viral antigens (M2e and HA2) combined with new adjuvant systems (including p97c derived from Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae). outcomes.description: The project produced comprehensive high-quality research and evidence on climate resilience and food systems in West Africa, focused on locally-driven adaptation solutions. Key research outputs included two scientific articles submitted to peer-reviewed journals (on farm ponds for supplemental irrigation and on the local champions approach for scaling good practices), multiple analytical reports on implementation and scaling of climate adaptation solutions, and a series of blog posts published in three languages (French, English, Spanish) on local expertise and food security. The project systematically capitalized and documented knowledge developed by communities and stakeholders in implementing supplemental irrigation systems and other climate adaptation practices, creating learning products and services including identification of local champions, learning routes, and learning territories. Research demonstrated important findings on holistic approaches to scaling locally-developed solutions, the balance between technical and social dimensions of adaptation, the role of local knowledge in agricultural advisory services, and methods for sharing and transferring skills needed for adoption and scaling of best practices by smallholder farmers.

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested an innovative farmer-to-farmer training approach in West Africa that valorized local knowledge by transforming smallholder farmers into trainers and service providers for climate adaptation practices. Local champions who had developed or adapted solutions such as supplemental irrigation systems and water collection basins (BCER) became the primary trainers rather than external technical experts, participating in the entire process from curriculum design to delivery and decision-making about learner selection. Vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers were actively involved in co-creating knowledge, piloting climate adaptation technologies, and testing best practices through hands-on learning experiences including farm visits and practical demonstrations. The project piloted methodologies including learning routes, learning territories, and identification of local champions, which were adapted to meet specific project needs and local contexts. This innovative approach institutionalized a knowledge-sharing ecosystem and demonstrated a cost-effective model for agricultural advisory services that could function in insecure contexts while empowering farmers and improving food security and climate resilience.
quotes: Le projet visait à tester une approche pratique de gestion locale des savoirs pour renforcer l'application à grande échelle des solutions d'adaptation et de résilience agricole

Cette approche qui valorise les connaissances locales détenues par les acteurs locaux a bouleversé les relations de hiérarchie puisque ce sont les agriculteurs qui sont devenus les formateurs. Ceux-ci ont participé à tout le processus de préparation des formations et aux prises de décision, notamment en ce qui a trait à la définition des critères de sélection des apprenants, ainsi que la quantité d'apprenants par pratique.
Rapport : « Mise en œuvre, mise en valeur et mise à l'échelle d'une solution d'adaptation au changement climatique en Afrique de l'Ouest ». 2020.

Il démontre également la pertinence d'une transmission des savoirs construite autour du rôle des champions locaux (qui ont développé ou adapté une solution locale), qui non seulement deviennent les formateurs (plutôt que les techniciens externes qui jouent normalement ce rôle), mais participent à part entière au processus d'échange et de transmission des savoirs et des pratiques les plus appropriées.

outcomes.description: This one-year project generated significant knowledge and research outputs on COVID-19's impact on food systems and gender dynamics in West Africa. Key scientific contributions included two peer-reviewed articles published in international journals (Sustainability and International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health) examining pandemic effects on food security vulnerabilities and gender inequalities, plus three advocacy notes addressing health measures, women's resilience roles, and cross-border trade impacts. The research conducted an extensive PRISMA literature review that identified critical gaps in gender-differentiated pandemic impacts and documented how government restrictions (rather than the disease itself) disrupted food systems, forced illegal cross-border trade, and triggered a reconfiguration of gender power relations as women took on key economic roles. The project produced evidence-based policy recommendations for future pandemic responses that address local contexts, support food system resilience, and maintain gender equality gains, providing critical understanding not only of the COVID crisis but of future shocks to food security.

outcomes.description: This project successfully developed and tested mycorrhiza-based biostimulants as a climate-resilient innovation for Algerian agriculture, involving vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers throughout the process. The innovation involved isolating five new mycorrhizal strains endemic to Algerian soil, conducting greenhouse experimentation under challenging conditions (including during COVID-19 lockdowns), and implementing on-farm trials with 188 farmers across three distinct bioclimates (arid, semi-arid, and sub-humid). These trials demonstrated significant yield increases ranging from 32% to 55% across different vegetable crops including olives, potatoes, tomatoes, and peppers. The project culminated in obtaining government homologation of the biostimulant product from the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development in December 2023, which paved the way for commercial production and private sector investment, including the establishment of a production facility with 400-ton annual capacity.

outcomes.description: The project generated comprehensive scientific research and evidence on mycorrhiza-based biostimulants for climate-resilient agriculture in Algeria. Through laboratory isolation of five endemic mycorrhizal strains from different bioclimates (arid, semi-arid, and sub-humid), greenhouse experimentation, and on-farm trials with 188 farmers, the project produced rigorous empirical evidence demonstrating yield increases of 32-55% across different vegetable crops in three main agro-ecological zones. outcomes.description: The project engaged vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers in developing, testing, and piloting multiple climate-smart innovations throughout the sorghum value chain in Ethiopia. Over 8,523 farmers (16% women-headed households) directly participated in on-farm demonstrations and testing of seven early-maturing drought-tolerant sorghum varieties (Argity, Tilahun, Melkam, Kalu, Alene, Dekeba, Girana 1, and Fadis), with more than 12,000 additional farmers accessing seeds through local exchange networks. Farmers were actively involved in evaluating and providing feedback on three different types of mechanical threshers, leading to redesign and modifications that increased threshing efficiency from 1.15 to 1.63 tonnes per hectare per hour. Over 4,000 farmers (48% women) participated in demonstrations and training on post-harvest storage technologies including PICS bags and metal silos, while women's groups tested optimized injera-making protocols using dehulled sorghum. The co-creation process involved farmers testing innovations for transpiration efficiency, root architecture, biomass production, and various value-added products, with farmer preferences directly shaping technology selection and adaptation.
quotes: To address key limitations to sorghum production and availability to smallholders in Ethiopia, the project developed and deployed key technologies that reduce the risk of crop failure, increase productivity and create new economic opportunities for women businesses. outcomes.description: The project generated substantial research evidence and outputs on climate-resilient sorghum production in Ethiopia. Key research findings included quantitative data on root architecture (with root angles ranging from 14.04 to 19.50 degrees) demonstrating that narrow root angle traits lead to enhanced grain yield in drought-prone conditions, and studies on transpiration efficiency for selecting high biomass varieties. The project produced at least 10 major research outputs including a research report on gender disparities in sorghum production, theses on genetic variability and root architecture analysis, and studies on genetic dissection of root architecture and transpiration efficiency, canopy development, leaf anatomy impacts, nutritional evaluation for poultry, and women's empowerment measurement using Pro-WEAI. outcomes.description: The project produced extensive scientific evidence and research outputs on bacteriocins as alternatives to antibiotics in poultry production to address antimicrobial resistance. The research produced 8 peer-reviewed scientific articles published in high-impact journals, a well-characterized bank of antibiotic-resistant bacterial pathogens from Tunisian poultry farms, and a unique collection of bacteriocin-producing intestinal strains with demonstrated antimicrobial activity against Salmonella and E. coli. The project generated rigorous data on bacteriocin safety, bioavailability, and inhibitory activity under avian digestive conditions, with optimized production and purification processes that resulted in a patent (US 11,571,456 B2). Three bacteriocins (microcin J25, enterocin L50A/B, and brevibacillin) were selected and tested through in vitro and in vivo trials in experimental poultry facilities, producing proof-of-concept evidence that microcin J25 can serve as a growth promoter and reduce Salmonella and E. coli carriage comparable to conventional antibiotics (bacitracin and oxytetracycline).

outcomes.description: This project developed and tested bacteriocins as innovative therapeutic and prophylactic alternatives to antibiotics in poultry production to address antimicrobial resistance. The research team selected three specific bacteriocins (microcin J25, enterocin L50A/B, and brevibacillin) and developed optimized production and purification processes at pilot scale, some of which resulted in a patent (US 11,571,456 B2). Three in vivo trials in experimental poultry facilities (two in Canada and one in Tunisia) validated that microcin J25 demonstrated antimicrobial power comparable to commonly used antibiotics (bacitracin and oxytetracycline), showing potential as a growth promoter and for reducing intestinal carriage of Salmonella and E. coli. The bacteriocins also demonstrated the capacity to reduce Salmonella presence on chicken carcasses by 3 logs and extend shelf life by 3 days, thereby reducing food poisoning risks and improving food safety. The project achieved proof-of-concept for bacteriocin-based probiotic formulations to compete with and suppress intestinal pathogens in broiler chickens, representing a significant technological innovation for the poultry sector in developing countries.

outcomes.description: This project developed and field-tested an innovative bacteriophage cocktail composed of 4 phages (2 from Kenya and 2 from Université Laval collection) as an alternative to antibiotics for controlling Salmonella infections in Kenyan poultry farms. The research team isolated and characterized 16 Salmonella strains and 67 new phages from Kenyan poultry farms and slaughterhouses, with the selected phage cocktail showing notable efficiency against tested Salmonella strains in broilers and Kienyeji chicken when administered orally through drinking water. Three of the four phages were successfully spray-dried into a powdered product that can be shipped without cold chain requirements, and the delivery method was specifically adapted based on consultations with women farmers who preferred water-based delivery over feed due to varying feed quality. Field trials were conducted at ILRI Kapiti Ranch in August 2023, demonstrating that vulnerable communities and smallholder farmers were meaningfully involved in co-creating, testing, and shaping the product development process. The project exemplifies integration of gender-responsive strategies throughout the innovation development cycle, with a dedicated gender study identifying women farmers as a key target group to facilitate acceptance of phage-based products by the chicken farmer community.

outcomes.description: The project successfully developed and tested an innovative nanoparticle-based vaccine (VXN-E.coli) for preventing avian colibacillosis in poultry as an alternative to antibiotics. The vaccine formulation included inactivated bacteria from the three most prevalent Avian Pathogenic Escherichia Coli (APEC) serotypes and lipidated starch nanoparticles, tested through eight in vivo vaccination experiments using various administration methods including in ovo, subcutaneous, mucosal, and intramuscular routes. Field trials were conducted on 3000 eggs in an industrial hatchery using automated vaccination systems, demonstrating that the nanovaccine successfully protected chickens against field strains of E.coli, proved compatible with commercial combined vaccines (Marek, Newcastle, and Infectious bursal disease), and showed excellent safety, tolerance, and no negative effects on hatchability, mortality, or performance parameters over 45 days. A formulation patent was filed in February 2023, and the project achieved proof of concept, leading to its selection for continued funding in InnoVet-AMR 2.0 to further advance toward commercialization.

The innovation was piloted and tested through in vitro experiments demonstrating the ability to block rotavirus attachment to porcine intestinal epithelial cells, followed by in vivo trials with gnotobiotic piglets at Ohio State University and conventional pigs at the University of Nairobi. outcomes.description: This project produced substantial southern-based research and evidence on women-led grocery stokvels (rotating savings and credit associations) and their role in food security and healthy food access in South Africa. The research outputs included two published peer-reviewed papers (a systematic review on informal savings groups and food security, and a stakeholder mapping exercise), plus two additional manuscripts under preparation. The project conducted a realist evaluation to understand individual and collective agency in food purchasing decisions, and discrete choice experiments (DCE) to investigate incentives for healthy food choices among stokvels. Additional knowledge products included a dedicated webpage presenting findings in accessible layperson's terms for stakeholders and local government actors, informational resources on healthy meals and food storage, and a social media community page for stokvel engagement. The research generated critical findings about the significant role stokvels play in household food security, economic empowerment, and social support for women, while also revealing gaps in prioritization of nutrition and health, as well as limitations in stokvels' leverage within the broader food system dominated by large retailers.

outcomes.description: The project successfully developed, piloted, and tested multiple climate and food system innovations with vulnerable communities in Morocco and Senegal, with particular emphasis on upgrading milk value chains. In Morocco, innovations included agroforestry systems with atriplex combined with annual crops, irrigated forages (blue panicum, barley, forage corn, berseem, and sorghum), and barley hydroponics for fodder production that produced 500 kg/day of green fodder. The project also tested herd upgrading interventions including introduction of pure dairy breeds, adoption of improved feed rations, adequate goat shed layouts, and adoption of best hygiene and production practices, which increased milk production from 0.3 to 2 liters/day/goat. Organizational innovations were developed through the structuration of an inclusive dairy value chain involving the establishment of six cooperatives (five for milk production and one for milk processing), employing a robust bottom-up value chain approach to diagnose bottlenecks, design solutions, pilot them, and demonstrate impact. The project created proofs of concept and prototypes with communities to outline market development strategies for scaling up local dairy value chains, successfully achieved in Morocco though not in Senegal due to time and budget limitations.

outcomes.description: The project generated substantial high-quality research outputs on bovine babesiosis vaccine development, including the production and testing of multiple blood-stage antigens (BbSA7-18) and tick-stage antigens (HAP2), genome sequencing to redefine the N-terminus of 11C5, and characterization of vaccine candidate antigens for broad-range protection. The research team published four peer-reviewed papers and two invited reviews in international journals, filed a patent for a transmission-blocking vaccine at the United States Patent and Trademark Office, and presented findings at numerous national and international conferences including IBM III and IV at Yale University, WAAVP in Dublin, and conferences in Denmark, Romania, and Australia. Despite the final vaccine trial being inconclusive, the project generated significant technical knowledge disseminated through peer-reviewed publications that serves the research community and guides future vaccine development efforts for tick-borne livestock diseases. outcomes.description: The Adaptation Futures 2023 project developed and tested multiple innovations in conference design to enhance accessibility, inclusivity, and equity in scientific gatherings focused on climate adaptation. Key innovations included: (1) hybrid and distributed conference formats combining virtual and multi-hub approaches, tested through Regional Pavilions for Latin America/Caribbean (by Fundacion Avina) and Africa (by African Academy of Science); (2) a comprehensive support system including 207 travel grants, connectivity grants, visa support, and mentoring programs specifically for early-career researchers; (3) diverse session formats moving beyond traditional panels to include creative, co-creation, and embodied forms of interaction, with specific rooms equipped accordingly and virtual consultations offered to session hosts; and (4) multi-sited dialogue workshops testing different event formats (virtual, multi-hub, hybrid) as new models of knowledge exchange. These innovations successfully enabled participation from 1,000 in-person and 460 virtual participants from 127 countries, including over 110 Canadian Indigenous people, and generated research outputs documenting best practices for equitable, carbon-conscious scientific convenings.

outcomes.description: The project generated substantial research evidence and knowledge about CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing technology for enhanced avian vaccine production across multiple dimensions. RNA-seq analysis on IFITM knockout DF1 cells and LMH cells revealed significant upregulation of genes correlated with cellular membrane and plasma membrane signal transduction, with edited cells showing more pronounced responses to infection compared to non-edited cells. The research demonstrated proof of concept that knocking out the IFITM locus in chicken embryonic fibroblast cell lines increased viral yields for influenza and Newcastle disease viruses without compromising antigenicity, with testing confirming 1-2.5 log10 higher yields compared to traditional embryonated chicken eggs. The team developed valuable research tools including DF1 single-cell clones with single IFITM knockouts, DF1 cells stably expressing flag-tagged IFITMs, and was the first to describe the antiviral roles, locations, and interactions of quail IFITMs with viruses. Two peer-reviewed publications were in preparation for open-access journals, multiple conference presentations were delivered, and the findings advanced understanding of gene editing technology to provide more sustainable and cost-effective vaccine production methods for low- and middle-income countries.
quotes: RNA-seq analysis on IFITM knockout DF1 cells and LMH cells before and after influenza and NDV infection revealed significant upregulation of genes correlated with the cellular membrane and plasma membrane signal transduction, and edited cells showed a more pronounced response to infection compared to non-edited cells.

outcomes.description: The project produced high-quality research and technical evidence on innovative livestock vaccine development, including peer-reviewed publications in the journal Vaccines and presentations at international conferences such as the Vaccine Conference VIII in Spain. The research team developed and validated a novel non-replicative human adenovirus vector vaccine for Newcastle Disease, producing successful vaccine candidates with various formulations (liquid and solid), achieving 80-100% protection in chicken trials, and demonstrating vaccine stability under different storage conditions. The project generated critical methodological advances including Standard Operating Procedures and regulatory guidance documents for viral vector-based recombinant vaccines, providing essential technical knowledge for vaccine registration and manufacturing in Ethiopia. Technology transfer sessions and capacity building activities were conducted, training one postdoctoral scientist from Tunisia and 8 scientists from Ethiopia's National Veterinary Institute in bioreactor operation, cell culture technologies, and vaccine manufacturing processes. This research addressed critical gaps in cost-effective and safe Newcastle Disease vaccines for Africa, contributing to the evidence base for climate-resilient livestock production systems and food security.

outcomes.description: The Adaptation Research Alliance (ARA) was successfully launched at COP26 and significantly strengthened over the project period, nearly doubling in size to over 230 member organizations across 63 countries. The Alliance established itself as a valuable multi-actor coalition bridging global policy processes (including UNFCCC engagement) to grassroots activities of local universities and community-based organizations, while connecting research, funding, policy, and community organizations with a common goal to accelerate action-oriented adaptation research in developing countries. Through its growth and maturation, the Alliance facilitated co-creation processes among members on nature-based solutions for equitable resilience in Sub-Saharan Africa and enabled LDC universities to contribute to national adaptation, while also strengthening IDRC's partnerships with key actors such as FCDO through the CLARE initiative. The Alliance refined its organizational structure and value proposition, establishing its primary function as 'Building Communities & Networks' and creating new connections with novel actors such as Community Jameel and India Climate Collaborative, though it continues to face challenges in governance, funding, and balancing secretariat responsibilities with member engagement.

The project completed and published eight peer-reviewed case studies documenting diverse applications of intersectional research approaches in IDRC-funded initiatives, all made available on the lead organization's website. project_name: Évaluation de l’impact socio-économique

outcomes.description: The project successfully produced high-quality research evidence on the socio-economic impact of animal diseases in Senegal's agropastoral livestock sector. Key research outputs included: (1) quantitative estimates showing annual economic losses of 357 billion FCFA from animal diseases in small ruminant farming, with losses attributed to production losses (73%), mortality (22%), and health expenditures (5%); (2) a comprehensive mapping of the livestock data ecosystem identifying 14 relevant datasets on domestic ruminant production and health; (3) development and demonstration of the feasibility of the GBADs (Global Burden of Animal Diseases) methodology for estimating animal disease impacts using existing data, representing an important methodological contribution applicable to similar contexts; and (4) planned publication of scientific articles and communication documents for livestock keepers. The project generated critical evidence to support prioritization of policy and investment decisions in animal disease prevention and control, contributing to improved understanding of barriers to livestock development in developing countries.
quotes: Dans le cadre de ce projet, l'équipe de recherche évaluera à l'échelle nationale l'impact des maladies animales, y compris les pertes et les dépenses, au niveau de l'élevage des petits ruminants en milieu extensif agropastoral.

Le projet de recherche a réalisé une démonstration de la faisabilité de l'implémentation de l'approche GBADs dans le contexte du secteur agropastoral des petits ruminants au Sénégal. Cette initiative a permis de générer rapidement des résultats exploitables concernant les pertes dues aux maladies animales dans le secteur de l'élevage à l'échelle nationale.

Une cartographie exhaustive de l'écosystème des données existantes sur l'élevage au Sénégal a été effectuée. Cette cartographie constitue une ressource précieuse sur laquelle d'autres études utilisant l'approche GBADs pourront s'appuyer.

Le projet GBADs au Sénégal a développé et démontré la faisabilité de l'approche GBADs pour estimer l'impact des maladies animales sur la production et les dépenses en utilisant des données existantes. Cela représente une contribution méthodologique importante pour évaluer l'impact des maladies animales dans des contextes similaires.
Dans l'ensemble, ces études de cas ont soutenu les efforts visant à mieux comprendre les obstacles au développement de l'élevage dans les pays en développement.

filename: PCR109055 Integrated quorum quenching strategies to reduce antimicrobial resistance in shrimp aquaculture.pdf
project_name: Integrated quorum quenching strategies to reduce antimicrobial resistance in shrimp aquaculture

outcomes.description: This project successfully developed and tested three novel quorum-sensing technologies as innovative alternatives to antimicrobials for controlling Vibrio infections in shrimp aquaculture, with shrimp fed quorum quenching probiotics demonstrating high growth rates and reduced Vibrio counts compared to control groups. The innovations included: a benthic diatom (Halamphora sp.) and its associated bacteria as probiotic candidates tested in algae-biofloc and probiotic feed forms; mass production of microalgae and quorum quenching molecules in cost-effective bioreactors; and green-water culture systems that promote shrimp health and growth. The project achieved proof-of-concept through field trials and clinical studies conducted across seven shrimp farms in different geographical regions of Peninsular Malaysia, with results demonstrating increased survivability and body weight of shrimp that could lead to increased revenue for farmers. Additionally, the team investigated technology uptake by farmers, finding that 63.4% (n=78) of shrimp farmers demonstrated high knowledge about the technologies and 74% (n=91) expressed intention to adopt new and improved technologies, providing crucial insights for future commercialization.
quotes: This project determined the best application methods of quorum quenchers to reduce Vibrio infections and antimicrobial resistance in a simple and cost-effective approach... The technology uptake by farmers (particularly women farmers) was also investigated.

Three potential quorum sensing technologies for reducing vibrio infections in shrimp were developed. The shrimp fed with the quorum quenching probiotics demonstrated high growth rate and less vibrio counts compared to the control shrimp.

For example, the team sought to use chicken anti-quorum sensing IgY antibodies as quorum quenchers. They tried immunizing chicken embryos but got inconsistent immune response results. They also tried mice to induce anti-quorum sensing molecules IgG with good results, but low amounts were purified. outcomes.description: The project successfully developed and optimized an innovative attenuated live Heartwater vaccine for domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, and goats), achieving a complete transition from blood-based vaccines to cell culture-produced vaccines that eliminate risks of disease transmission, reduce cold storage requirements, and remove the need for animals in production. Three large-scale pilot batches were produced at Onderstepoort Biological Products (OBP) with consistent parameters and passed quality control tests, contributing to future vaccine registration requirements. The project achieved two of its four main objectives: developing and optimizing alternative vaccine production methods and improving vaccine stability through lyophilisation to remove dependence on cold chain for storage and transportation. However, final animal trials did not demonstrate immune protection, resulting in no vaccine registration, and technology transfer to the Centre for Ticks and Tick-Borne Diseases (CTTBD) in Malawi was only partially completed, becoming subject to legal arbitration. Despite these setbacks, the project generated important knowledge on vaccine production processes and innovations relevant to livestock health and food security in Africa.

outcomes.description: This project produced substantial high-quality research evidence and outputs on developing a novel chemically synthesized capsular polysaccharide (CPS)-based vaccine against Streptococcus suis in swine. The research generated a panel of eight pure, structurally defined antigenic fragments of S. suis serotype 2 CPS, developed analytical tests for characterization, standardized a reliable challenge model validated under Thai swine production systems, and achieved proof-of-concept demonstrating significant protection in weaned piglets—the first such vaccine in veterinary medicine. Multiple research outputs were produced including peer-reviewed open access journal articles (Pathogens 2019, Foods 2022), conference presentations at international workshops, lay publications for stakeholders, a patent cooperation treaty filing, and contributed to scientific knowledge across molecular genetics, pathology, biochemistry, immunology, vaccinology, and microbiology. The research addressed antimicrobial resistance by developing alternatives to antibiotics for livestock health, with findings presented at conferences reaching students, scientists, and pharmaceutical industry investors, while the 5th International Workshop on Streptococcus suis attracted diverse participation (42% women participants, 50% women speakers, 47% women poster presenters).

The team used unique and creative chemical synthesis and knowledge-based approaches to produce a panel of eight pure, structurally defined antigenic fragments of S. suis serotype 2 CPS as well as modified fragments with potential cross-reactivity that would broaden vaccine coverage to other clinically relevant serotypes.

project_name: Investigating the use of nanobubble technology in aquaculture

outcomes.description: The project produced substantial high-quality research evidence on nanobubble technology applications in aquaculture across multiple countries, generating 17 published open-access scientific papers, 7 industry workshops, and 6 scientific presentations. The research contributed to multiple scientific disciplines including bacteriology, immunology, molecular genetics, vaccinology, pathology, bioinformatics, and microbiology, creating a wealth of data on the use of oxygen and ozone nanobubbles for pathogen control, vaccine efficacy enhancement, water quality improvement, and antimicrobial reduction in aquaculture systems. Key scientific findings included: effectiveness of ozone nanobubbles in reducing bacteria in water, safety for fish health, mortality reduction during disease outbreaks, immune system stimulation prior to vaccination, and potential for removing antibiotics from aquatic environments through membrane filtration. The research influenced private sector development of nanobubble equipment specifically designed for aquaculture use and established nanobubble services at City University of Hong Kong's veterinary service, while also producing a publicly available app (https://nanobubbles.shinyapps.io/nanobubble_flow/) to help farmers understand costs and equipment requirements.

outcomes.description: This project generated substantial high-quality research and scientific knowledge on antimicrobial peptides in aquaculture, specifically characterizing and testing PACAP (pituitary adenylate cyclase-activating polypeptide) variants as alternatives to antibiotics for treating microbial infections in fish and shrimp. The research team completed functional characterization of PACAP variants, developed and standardized multiple assays for immune response assessment, established challenge models, and demonstrated in vitro efficacy against seven major aquatic pathogens (Flavobacterium psychrophilum, Flavobacterium columnare, Aeromonas hydrophila, Aeromonas salmonicida, Streptococcus iniae, Vibrio anguillarum, and Yersinia ruckeri). The research successfully achieved proof-of-concept demonstrating that PACAP can be used across different aquatic species including rainbow trout, tilapia, Clarias, shrimp, and crayfish, generating a wealth of data, resources, challenge models, and in vitro assays that are scarce in aquaculture research and can be utilized for future funding applications.

project_name: Polyvalent vaccine for freshwater catfish

outcomes.description: This project successfully developed and tested multiple climate and food system innovations for freshwater catfish aquaculture as alternatives to antibiotics. Three prototype vaccines were developed (monovalent Edwardsiella ictaluri, monovalent Aeromonas, and a polyvalent vaccine containing antigens for E. ictaluri, A. hydrophila, and A. dhakensis), with the novel immersion vaccine designed to reduce fish handling and stress during vaccination. The project achieved proof-of-concept testing for robotic vaccination technology that reduces labor intensity and fish stress, with successful validation of vaccination system parameters for fish at 10-30g. These innovations were developed based on behavioral studies, choice experiments, and surveys of 400 farmers to understand barriers and catalysts to vaccine adoption, with the innovations subsequently tested through workshops and training sessions involving 60 fish farmers and 15 Vietnamese researchers.

outcomes.description: The project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research evidence on gender and intersectionality in livestock vaccine value chains across three countries. Key knowledge outputs included: the first-ever comprehensive mappings of livestock vaccine value chains (LVVC) for Newcastle Disease and Peste des Petits Ruminants incorporating gender and intersectional analysis; development and operationalization of a Gender-Intersectional Transformative Approach (GITA) tool/methodology for analyzing vaccine distribution chains; peer-reviewed publications demonstrating that ethnic, caste, and other intersectional differences can override gender differences in determining exclusion and marginality; innovative use of the Women's Empowerment in Livestock Index (WELI) to compare empowerment across intersectional groups (beyond just women/men); and a meta-analysis documenting barriers, opportunities, and scalable interventions for women's participation in LVVCs. The project also produced an impressive array of training materials in 8 languages tailored to specific ethnic groups (distributed via 200 memory sticks and over 10,000 physical copies), policy briefs for each country, and research demonstrating the value of integrating soft skills training with technical veterinary education. These research outputs advanced understanding of how to address localized, context-specific barriers to women's empowerment in livestock systems and demonstrated the significance of qualitative research methods in this technical field.

outcomes.outcome_type: Sustained Gender Equality and Inclusion Transformations
outcomes.description: This project achieved sustained gender equality and inclusion transformations through multiple interconnected approaches. First, it pioneered the use of a Gender-Intersectional Transformative Approach (GITA) in livestock systems, demonstrating that gender differences are not the only barriers—ethnic, caste, disability, age, remoteness, and marital status differences can override gender in determining exclusion and marginality. Second, the project developed extensive gender-inclusive and intersectional training materials in 8 languages, distributed over 10,000 physical copies and 200 memory sticks to stakeholders, and integrated soft skills (gender, facilitation, empathic listening, communication, conflict management, and entrepreneurship) into training for technical animal health practitioners. Third, endline findings demonstrated that both men and women were starting to challenge socio-cultural norms about women and take action to create more inclusion in livestock vaccine value chains to improve their livelihoods and animal health. Fourth, interventions targeting intersectional barriers to accessing animal health services and vaccines were shown to impact underlying gender and other norms, empowering women and members of other disadvantaged groups to effectively contribute and benefit from livestock vaccine value chains. The project also pioneered the use of the Women's Empowerment in Livestock Index (WELI) to compare empowerment across various intersectional groups beyond just women and men, informing further development of the tool.
quotes: Using a Gender-Intersectional Transformative Approach (GITA), demonstrated that gender differences are not the only ones that matter – intersectional analysis is essential to unveil sites of exclusion and marginality in livestock vaccine distribution systems: in some cases, ethnic and caste differences can override those determined by gender.
