outcomes.description: The project successfully elevated diverse southern perspectives on gender-transformative approaches to livestock vaccine value chains through multiple channels. The research team, comprising local organizations and researchers from Nepal, Senegal, and Uganda in partnership with the University of Florida, produced high-quality research outputs including peer-reviewed publications, policy briefs in multiple languages (8 languages total), and training materials adapted to local contexts with culturally specific visual representations for different ethnic groups. project_name: Gender Inclusive Vaccine Distribution and Delivery for ND and PPR in Kenya

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested innovative vaccine delivery models for Newcastle Disease (ND) and Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR) vaccines in Kenya, using an experimental design with six intervention arms that integrated technical and gender educational components. Two specific delivery models were piloted: a demand-driven model and a community vaccinator (CV) driven model, both demonstrating viability in increasing vaccine uptake (ND vaccination rates nearly doubled from 33% to 64%) and improving livestock health in remote, marginal agricultural areas. The project involved smallholder farmers—particularly women—in co-creating and testing these innovations through training, awareness creation, stakeholder engagement, and the use of peer community vaccinators supervised by animal health professionals. Key innovations included the integration of gender-transformative approaches with vaccine delivery, application of the Women's Empowerment in Livestock Index (WELI) tool, and establishment of formal and informal collective action structures (cooperatives and groups) to enhance vaccine access and distribution. The project generated important lessons about sustainability of vaccine services in climate-vulnerable areas, the need for CV accreditation and close supervision, and the effectiveness of both formal and informal collective structures in mobilizing farmers for vaccination and training activities.
quotes: The project uses an experimental design with six intervention arms to test whether adding technical and gender educational components to vaccine delivery can address gender based constraints and social norms that prevent women from accessing, using and benefiting from livestock vaccines as well as address vaccine awareness and access.

outcomes.description: Smallholder chicken farmers in Kenya adopted multiple climate resilience and food system innovations through this project. Vaccination rates for Newcastle Disease (ND) nearly doubled from 33% to 64%, with farmers reporting better flock health, reduced mortality, and increased productivity. Farmers adopted improved husbandry practices including routine vaccination, regular cleaning of chicken houses, synchronized hatching, selecting eggs for hatching, and daily cleaning of watering equipment. There was a gradual shift from individual to collective marketing, with farmers realizing benefits of better prices and prompt payment. Additionally, livestock service delivery actors adopted a new community vaccinator (CV) model for vaccine distribution and delivery in remote areas, demonstrating that CVs working under close supervision by trained animal health assistants or veterinarians can effectively increase vaccine uptake and improve livestock health. Some farmers demonstrated behavioral shifts by selling small ruminants (goats) to finance construction of improved chicken houses and scale up poultry production, showing increased investment interest in poultry as a viable income source.

outcomes.description: The project systematically tested gender transformative approaches against gender accommodative (responsive) approaches, demonstrating that gender transformative interventions were significantly more effective in changing restrictive social and gender norms and empowering women in livestock systems. Endline results showed marked improvements in women's empowerment, particularly in gender transformative approach communities, with evidence of norm change becoming less restrictive and affecting women's participation in livestock rearing, decision-making power, and access to animal health services. The project documented that these restrictive norms must first be addressed for technical livestock interventions to meaningfully support women's empowerment, with 3,000 people attending participatory sessions to reflect on cultural attitudes and gender norms, and 105 women becoming lead farmers trained in vaccine administration. outcomes.description: This project significantly increased knowledge production on Senegalese food systems, nutrition transition, and the triple burden of malnutrition through multiple research outputs and datasets. The project conducted a comprehensive national survey on dietary habits and developed a detailed food composition table for Senegal—critical tools that were previously lacking in the country and region. Research outputs included studies on household consumption patterns and nutritional food baskets, food distribution circuits and purchasing practices, sociocultural factors in food choices (particularly among women), and elasticity of food demand for fiscal policy simulation. The project produced evidence on the relationship between diet and non-communicable diseases in West Africa, a domain that previously suffered from a significant scarcity of research, and established a solid evidence base for public policy interventions regarding universal access to healthy food in Senegal. These research outputs encompassed a final technical report with multiple annexes, qualitative survey reports, and the nationally representative food composition table, all contributing to understanding the economic, social, cultural, and political dimensions of food systems and public health.

outcomes.description: The Think Climate Indonesia initiative supported five Indonesian think tanks to produce extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience and food systems. The think tanks completed collaborative applied research projects, policy analyses, and studies addressing climate mitigation and adaptation challenges including urban food systems, agroforestry practices, social forestry and food security, forest and land rehabilitation, climate budget tagging, and sustainable palm oil management. outcomes.description: The Think Climate Indonesia initiative significantly improved understanding of climate and food system issues among decision-makers through multiple pathways. Five Indonesian think tanks conducted high-quality research and engaged over 500 policy audiences through presentations, forums, workshops, and media collaborations, directly reaching government ministries (Ministry of Development Planning, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Environment and Forestry, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Home Affairs), political parties, and presidential candidates who subsequently requested meetings to discuss inserting climate change into political agendas. The research generated evidence-based policy recommendations on critical issues including climate budget allocation, forest and land rehabilitation, urban food systems, social forestry and food security, and climate resilience governance, with comprehensive findings disseminated through 9 policy briefs, newsletters, an e-book, media articles, and the Think Climate Forum dialogue series reaching over 500 participants. Decision-makers at national and local levels gained improved understanding of specific barriers (unclear government roles, inadequate budget allocations, gender policy gaps) and concrete policy solutions (community involvement in forest management, climate budget tagging, integration of food systems into urban planning), with Pekalongan City and Central Java Province making initial commitments to incorporate research findings into climate adaptation action plans. Through intensive stakeholder engagement including youth camps, citizen science programs, climate field schools, and partnerships with over 50 civil society organizations, the initiative strengthened policy dialogue capabilities and established new coalitions connecting government officials, local authorities, civil society leaders, academics, youth groups, and media to advance climate action in Indonesia.

outcomes.description: This project significantly enhanced decision-makers' understanding of food system issues and policy solutions across East Africa through multiple evidence-generation activities. The project implemented the Food-EPI tool for the first time in Uganda and Tanzania, revealing that while food environment policy frameworks existed, there were significant gaps in implementation compared to international best practices, providing policymakers with clear roadmaps for improvement. Cost-of-illness studies quantified the economic burden of diabetes (US$620 million in Kenya, US$270 million in Tanzania, and US$3.8 billion in Uganda), incentivizing decision-makers to invest in NCD prevention policies. The project also documented for the first time the extent of unhealthy food and beverage marketing to children in Kenya (82% of food/drink advertisements were for unhealthy products during peak viewing hours), highlighting the need for marketing restrictions. Legal and political feasibility assessments demonstrated that front-of-pack nutrition labeling and child-directed marketing restrictions were feasible policy interventions, providing decision-makers with actionable policy options and adapted assessment tools for their contexts.
quotes: When decisionmakers become aware of the actual cost of diabetes, they could become incentivized to invest in policies and strategies for preventing diabetes and NCDs more broadly.

Policy briefs: 1. Enhancing healthy food policies to address nutritional related non-communicable diseases in Tanzania. 2. Economic Burden of Nutrition Related Non-Communicable Diseases in Kenya: Public Healthcare System Costing of Type 2 Diabetes.

outcomes.description: The project developed an adapted version of the FELIP (Feasibility of Effective Legal and Implementation Processes) tool to assess the legal and political feasibility of implementing healthy food environment policies in Kenya, Uganda, and Tanzania. This adaptation addressed a critical gap in the traditional FELIP framework by incorporating not only which policies are possible to implement but also the probability of their success. outcomes.description: The project developed and tested multiple climate adaptation innovations for cocoa production with vulnerable communities in Côte d'Ivoire. Key innovations included: (1) a gender-sensitive decision-making tool for cocoa cooperatives that integrated climate scenarios, interpretation, and analysis of agroecological adaptation practices, which was tested, used, and disseminated through the national extension system (ANADER); (2) improved composting techniques using cocoa residues; and (3) improved solar dryers for cocoa beans that maximize solar energy and air circulation. The project also characterized and implemented endogenous agroecological practices and agroforestry systems with cocoa producers, including tree planting for shade, vegetative barriers, and other agroforestry benefits. The development and testing process involved cocoa cooperatives throughout all stages, including their boards of directors, staff, committee representatives, and diverse members ensuring female participation, constituting a comprehensive exercise in climate change impact communication and adaptation planning.
quotes: Le projet a produit un outil d'aide à la décision sensible au genre pour les coopératives cacaoyères en faveur de l'adaptation aux changements climatiques. outcomes.outcome_type: Improved Understanding of Climate and Food System Issues and Policy Solutions
outcomes.description: The project significantly improved understanding of climate risks, agroecological adaptation practices, and gender equality integration among multiple stakeholder groups. Research partners and extension agents enhanced their comprehension of climate-related risks and effective adaptation solutions, with project findings enriching extension curricula and decision-making tools. Three participating cocoa cooperatives developed heightened awareness of climate change issues, questioning their adaptive capacities and identifying concrete means to address climate challenges, which led to revisions of their foundational documents, internal regulations, and operational planning to anchor climate adaptation and gender equality commitments. Program managers and decision-makers gained improved understanding of effective policy solutions, specifically recognizing cooperative capacity strengthening as an increasingly effective strategy for building smallholder farmer resilience to climate and other external shocks. The project also produced and disseminated a gender-sensitive decision-support tool for cocoa cooperatives that was tested, utilized, and shared with national extension services (ANADER) through training workshops.

outcomes.description: The project significantly strengthened capacity for gender equality and inclusion among multiple actors including research partners, cocoa cooperatives, and extension services. Research partners and cooperatives developed improved understanding and openness to gender equality concepts, leading to integration of gender considerations in research and communication activities. The project developed culturally appropriate strategies and tools to ensure meaningful women's participation, including gender-sensitive survey tools and support strategies (advance notice, accommodating women's schedules, direct phone contact, cooperative support in recruitment). project_name: Promotion of Social Entrepreneurship in Disaster Risk Reduction to Build Community Resilience Malaysia and Cambodia

outcomes.description: The project produced extensive southern-based research outputs on climate resilience and disaster risk reduction, including the development of a drought susceptibility index (DSI) at the community level using novel approaches for landslides, slope failures, coastal inundation, and subsidence. Multiple peer-reviewed publications were produced in high-impact journals, including research on agricultural cooperatives in drought risk management published in Water and Sustainability journals, and findings were disseminated through 12 triannual reports, conference presentations, and IRDR working papers. The project created new multihazard-forecasting knowledge that integrates disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) using hazards-susceptibility mapping, GIS technology, and crowdsourced information through the MyBahaya platform. This research included downscaling climate data and projections, parameterization and ranking, and comprehensive assessment of hazard, exposure, and vulnerability across coastal zones, floodplains, and highland areas. The knowledge produced serves as the basis for disaster resilience plans in Kampong Speu Province (supporting 59 agriculture cooperatives) and informed the Selangor Policy and Action Plan on Climate Change, with the innovative approaches published to inspire scientists from developing countries to use best available science.
quotes: The development of a drought susceptibility index (DSI) at the community level has enabled the delineation of areas for priority action. The new approach has been published in journals to inspire scientists from developing countries to be innovative in using the best available science.

Chhinh, N., Sok, S., Sou, V., & Nguonphan, P. 2023. Roles of Agricultural Cooperatives (ACs) in Drought Risk Management among Smallholder Farmers in Pursat and Kampong Speu Provinces, Cambodia. Water, 15(8): 1447.

Knowledge advancement in the four select pilots focused primarily on susceptibility modelling after conducting downscaling climate data and projections, parameterization and ranking, and assessment of hazard, exposure, and vulnerability. The forecasting of fast- and slow-onset hazards using susceptibility modelling has yielded novel approaches for landslides, slope failures, coastal inundation, and subsidence.

Using GIS and crowdsourced information, the project created new multihazard-forecasting knowledge that integrates DRR and CCA using hazards-susceptibility mapping and will be used to develop disaster resilience plans for selected communities.

outcomes.description: The project developed and field-tested several climate and disaster risk innovations with meaningful community involvement across Malaysia and Cambodia. The MyBahaya Platform, a community-based GIS application using crowdsourcing technology, was created, tested, and launched to facilitate citizen reporting of geohazard early warning signs through photo-based mobile data collection. Drought susceptibility indices (DSI) were developed at the community level in Cambodia to enable priority action delineation, with these innovations serving as the basis for disaster resilience plans across multiple pilot locations (Kuala Selangor, Shah Alam, Ampang Jaya in Malaysia, and Kampong Speu in Cambodia). Young people (at least 30% of pilot populations), early career geologists, and 100,000 young women (ages 20-40) were actively engaged as catalysts in crowdsourcing hazard information and developing these disaster resilience plans. The project also involved 59 agriculture cooperatives in Cambodia in developing business plans and roadmaps for social entrepreneurship in disaster risk reduction.

Crowdsourcing techniques were used to develop community-based GIS applications to overcome constraints in obtaining data on climate, environmental, and socioeconomic stressors. The project positively impacted 100,000 young women, who served as catalysts to promote broad civil society engagement and mobilize women social entrepreneurs to help develop disaster resilience plans.

outcomes.outcome_type: Improved Understanding of Climate and Food System Issues and Policy Solutions
outcomes.description: Government officials and policymakers at various levels in Malaysia and Cambodia demonstrated improved understanding of climate-related risks and disaster risk reduction solutions, leading to concrete policy actions and integration recommendations. In Malaysia, key project findings were presented to the Chief Minister, Executive Council, and Deputy State Secretary of Selangor State, resulting in strong recommendations to integrate climate change adaptation (CCA) and disaster risk reduction (DRR) at the local authority level and subsequent state funding of RM 290,000 to formulate the Selangor Policy and Action Plan on Climate Change. The project's disaster resilience plans served as the basis for local DRR strategies in both Selangor Darul Ehsan and Kampong Speu Province, benefiting 5.79 million people in Malaysia and 716,517 in Cambodia, while also supporting 59 agriculture cooperatives in Kampong Speu Province with enhanced understanding of drought management and resilience planning. Stakeholders, particularly policymakers in Malaysia, showed a perceptible change in attitude toward climate and gender issues, moving from initial lack of enthusiasm to acceptance of gender-responsive approaches to DRR and CCA.

outcomes.description: This project generated substantial high-quality research evidence on hemorrhagic septicemia vaccine development for livestock health in climate-resilient food systems. outcomes.description: This project produced substantial high-quality research evidence on T. solium control through a One Health approach in Madagascar, generating multiple peer-reviewed publications in journals such as Parasitology and PLOS Neglected Tropical Diseases on topics including disease diagnosis, prevalence, prevention, and adverse event management. The research validated an effective control model demonstrating significant reduction in porcine cysticercosis prevalence from 31-36% at baseline to 8% at final evaluation, and slight reduction in human taeniasis from 1.25% to 0.63%. Key knowledge outputs included baseline surveys on infection prevalence, attitudes towards vaccination, and economic costs associated with the disease, plus field evaluation of a novel vaccine adjuvant showing significantly better performance than current alternatives. Additional planned outputs include at least two more publications in 2024 covering intervention results and economic studies, plus completion of a PhD dissertation, with all knowledge contributing to Madagascar's National Plan for cysticercosis control and WHO AFRO's global protocols for managing adverse events in mass drug administration programs.

outcomes.description: The project developed, piloted, and validated a comprehensive One Health model for Taenia solium control based on pig vaccination using the Cysvax® vaccine, marking the largest One Health T. solium control program ever implemented and the first as a public health program. Key innovations tested included: alternative vaccine adjuvant formulations demonstrating significantly better performance than existing ones; diagnostic methods comparing Kato-Katz, PCR, and coproantigen tests; and a protocol for managing serious neurological adverse events during praziquantel-based mass drug administration that WHO AFRO is now promoting globally. outcomes.description: The DeLiVa project successfully designed, developed, and tested an innovative public-private partnership (PPP) franchising model for contagious caprine pleuropneumonia (CCPP) vaccine delivery in pastoral areas of Ethiopia, involving vulnerable pastoralist communities in co-creating and piloting this climate and food system innovation. The model engaged one franchise (Abyssinia AgroVet Import and Distribution plc), four franchisees operating veterinary drug shops, and 106 community-based animal health workers (CAHWs) who received refresher training to deliver vaccines using rigorous cold chain management. The first vaccination campaign successfully reached 333,000 goats across 16,634 households (with 28.1% female-headed households on average) and achieved 89.3% vaccination coverage, demonstrating that vaccination could be applied at scale as a preventive measure. The innovation proved economically viable, with franchisees generating 2,677,491 birr income (approximately five times the government's annual operational budget for veterinary services), while also improving availability, accessibility, and demand for CCPP vaccine and other veterinary products. The project also supported the National Veterinary Institute in producing over 1 million doses of PANVAC-certified CCPP vaccine and conducted extensive awareness campaigns reaching over 2,700 individuals, with 95% reporting awareness of the vaccination value chain.

project_name: Human Rights and Healthy Diets Research Support Initiative

outcomes.description: This project generated comprehensive high-quality research and evidence on human rights-based approaches to promoting healthy diets and food systems in low- and middle-income countries. Knowledge production included a systematic scoping review of international, regional, and national legal and policy documents; a Conceptual and Analytical Framework; three country-specific reports and evidence briefs for Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda; and a comprehensive Synthesis Report identifying knowledge gaps, capacity needs, barriers, and opportunities. The research produced detailed analyses of how human rights frameworks, legal instruments, and international treaties can support regulatory and fiscal interventions (such as sugar-sweetened beverage taxation, nutrition labeling, food reformulation, and marketing restrictions) to promote healthier food environments and prevent diet-related non-communicable diseases. All outputs were made available as open access publications and learning resources for researchers, civil society organizations, and policymakers, with findings disseminated through regional and global platforms including the UN Inter-Agency Task Force for Prevention and Control of NCDs.
quotes: to generate knowledge on how human rights frameworks, legal instruments and local and global actors can support a human rights-based approach to promoting healthy diets

A set of learning resources and tools (including Open Access publications) were produced to help researchers, civil society organizations, and policymakers improve their understanding and apply a human rights-based approach to promote healthy diets.

This research was important to fund because it generated knowledge through global and local research on the barriers, capacity gaps, lessons, and recommendations on the use of Human Rights-Based Approaches for policy and decision making for the promotion of healthy food environments in three countries of focus: Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda.

outcomes.description: This project generated an outstanding volume of high-quality, southern-based research documenting the impacts of COVID-19 and subsequent shocks (hurricanes, territorial conflicts, indigenous mobilizations) on Latin American food systems and family farming. The research outputs included 3 peer-reviewed papers (published in journals like Global Food Security and Social Science and Medicine), 23 conjuncture analyses, 3 policy briefs, 3 working papers, and over 125 media publications and radio interviews, making it one of the most comprehensive documentation sets on COVID-19's impact on food systems in Latin America and a major source for IDRC's landmark synthesis. The research produced critical evidence on key findings including: the central role of household socioeconomic level and assets in determining food insecurity across different types of crises; gender-differentiated impacts showing women-headed households had higher poverty rates and modified food strategies more than male counterparts; and how households' coping strategies (reducing diet quality, selling assets, cutting education/health spending) increased long-term vulnerability. outcomes.description: The project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience and nature-based solutions (NbS), generating 25 research outputs including 9 published peer-reviewed papers, 8 additional papers submitted in 2025, 2 fully open access datasets (on bias-corrected climate data and land surface modeling), 9 guidance and communications products, infographics, a digital book on social (in)equity in NbS, a video, and 4 dissertations (2 masters graduates completed, 1 masters and 1 PhD expected in 2025). The research produced novel and internationally recognized insights into the intersections of social equity, sustainability, and NbS through innovative methods including cutting-edge land surface modeling, climate projections showing increased extremes in water towers, plant species viability modeling under future warming scenarios, and in-depth case studies documenting how NbS can have differential impacts even within the same communities. Key scientific findings included: systematic synthesis of 9 categories and 32 subcategories of constraints to social equity in NbS based on 95 examples across southern Africa; evidence that equity-focused intentions don't necessarily translate to equitable outcomes; projections of 10-20% plant species turnover under 2°C warming; and documentation of how misguided afforestation efforts contradict ecological evidence. All outputs were made open access, and the research directly informed national and international policy processes including South Africa's Convention on Biological Diversity positions and a major UKRI funding program on equitable NbS in Sub-Saharan Africa.

outcomes.description: This project generated comprehensive new knowledge on climate-resilient and sustainable food systems in Kenya through multiple research outputs including 5 policy briefs (covering Bungoma County, Nairobi County, West Pokot County, and national-level findings) and 1 blog, plus attracting 16 media mentions. The research produced critical evidence on the role of micro and small enterprises (MSEs) in local food systems, revealing that food retail MSEs (predominantly women-owned) are the most influential actors with two-thirds of household food coming from these sources, and uncovering unexpected findings that women-owned MSEs significantly outperformed male counterparts in business earnings despite requiring less start-up capital. The project generated actionable policy recommendations on enabling MSEs to supply healthy and sustainable foods by addressing unfavorable business conditions, incoherent policies, high taxation, and lack of collective action, while also documenting consumer barriers to healthy food consumption including affordability perceptions, seasonal scarcities, and awareness gaps. This southern-based research successfully achieved all objectives related to understanding perceptions, incentives, barriers, and gender dynamics in the food retail sector, with findings disseminated to diverse stakeholders including policymakers and the private sector at both national and sub-national levels.

outcomes.description: This project produced high-quality, southern-based research evidence on food systems and nutrition in Tanzania through comprehensive data collection and analysis. Key research outputs included a nationally representative quantitative survey (the first of its kind in Tanzania on this topic) covering all administrative and climatic zones, and in-depth qualitative studies using mixed methods including ethnography, community mapping, interviews and focus discussions to understand diverse food environments across regions. The project generated unique datasets and insights on consumer food choice behaviors, barriers, and opportunities shaped by physical, economic, political and socio-cultural contexts, including gender analysis and audience segmentation identifying 5 distinct audience segments. Additional knowledge products included a co-developed communications framework, research reports, technical briefs, presentations, and planned journal publications and multimedia content, all addressing critical information gaps on consumer voices and food environments in Tanzania.

outcomes.description: The DIDEM project produced substantial high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience and sustainable coastal/marine ecosystem management in the West Indian Ocean region. Approximately 40 papers, theses, and reports were produced (about one-third with IDRC funding support), including peer-reviewed academic papers, open access datasets and maps, environmental flow assessments, impact evaluations of dams on ecosystem services, and early career researcher theses across four countries. The project established "standing knowledge labs" that continue as core research activities of IRD and collaborating universities, producing ongoing knowledge outputs and serving as hands-on learning sites. Reports and databases are now routinely used by local governments in multiple locations (Incomati river in Mozambique, Betsiboke in Madagascar, Comoros islands) and by the Nairobi Convention members. Knowledge was co-created with communities through living labs, school activities, and dialogues between beneficiaries and researchers, with outputs including videos, permanent websites, and methodology frameworks that informed regional ocean governance strategies.

outcomes.description: This project produced substantial high-quality research evidence on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) through machine learning approaches applied to two multidrug-resistant pathogens. The research team constructed comprehensive genotype and antibiotic resistance phenotype datasets for 1,312 Streptococcus pneumoniae and 172 Pseudomonas aeruginosa strains, developed machine learning prediction models for 8 antibiotics, and created bioinformatics tools and algorithms to orient treatment selection, assist in surveillance, and provide rationale for novel antibiotic generation. Key scientific outputs included multiple peer-reviewed open-access publications in journals such as Genome Medicine and hLife, revealing epidemiological dynamics of multidrug resistant clones and identifying a high-risk hypervirulent P. aeruginosa pathotype. The research advanced scientific knowledge across multiple fields including molecular genetics, pathology, bioinformatics, diagnostics, surveillance, microbiology, and artificial intelligence, generating a wealth of data and resources for future research applications globally, including in low- and middle-income countries.

outcomes.description: The fellowship generated diverse research outputs across climate adaptation topics from 18 individual fellows working in research, innovation, and policy streams. Research outputs included climate vulnerability mapping of livestock herders in northern Côte d'Ivoire, experimentation with climate-resilient agro-ecological practices in Senegal's Niayes zone, gender analysis of climate knowledge among farming communities in northern Benin, studies on population displacement due to climate change in southwestern Côte d'Ivoire, analysis of wildfire seasons and greenhouse gas reduction strategies, research on selective waste sorting and biofertilizer production in Burkina Faso, and studies on traditional agroforestry systems and women's contributions to climate resilience. Policy-focused research examined implementation of international climate regimes, legal and institutional frameworks for climate action, and governance of plant resources in decentralization contexts. project_name: Livestock keeping in a changing climate

outcomes.description: The project generated localized scientific evidence on greenhouse gas emissions from small ruminants in extensive systems across sub-Saharan Africa through controlled in vivo animal experiments using respiration chambers at ILRI. Key research findings included: Red Maasai sheep showing greater resilience to Haemonchus contortus parasite infection with lower enteric methane emissions compared to Dorper sheep; methane conversion factors (Ym) of 7-8% of gross energy intake, higher than IPCC default of 6.5%; N₂O emission factors from sheep dung and urine (0.01% and 0.02%) much lower than IPCC defaults (0.21% and 0.31%); and evidence that Calliandra calothyrsus supplementation reduces methane emissions by up to 32% while improving animal health and liveweight gain. The research produced three peer-reviewed scientific publications in international journals, four conference papers, multiple invited presentations at international symposia, and extensive dissemination through farmer leaflets and educational materials. A PhD student successfully defended their thesis based on this research, and the findings were communicated to stakeholders across Kenya, Africa, and internationally through presentations in Peru, Nepal, Brazil, UK, and Ethiopia.
quotes: The proposal aimed to generate localized scientific evidence by undertaking in vivo animal experiments in sheep and goats commonly found in sub-Saharan Africa using animal respiration chambers.

outcomes.description: The project tested multiple climate-smart livestock interventions directly with smallholder farmers through participatory engagement. Over 290 farmers across Kenya and Ethiopia were involved in testing innovations including Calliandra calothyrsus supplementation for improving animal productivity while reducing methane emissions. The project distributed approximately 300 Calliandra seeds per farmer during direct on-farm engagements in Kenya, and processed 5 kg of seeds for biosecurity approval to be shipped to Ethiopia for seedling production and distribution. Farmers received comprehensive educational materials and leaflets explaining how to use Calliandra tree forage as a tool for tackling nutritional and health stressors while contributing to climate mitigation and adaptation. Instructions for establishment and use of Calliandra were published and distributed extensively. The direct farmer engagement approach proved more effective than traditional workshop methods for communicating climate adaptation strategies and enabling farmers to test solutions in their own contexts. The innovations tested addressed multiple challenges simultaneously: improving feed quality during dry seasons, reducing parasite loads, enhancing liveweight gain, and significantly lowering greenhouse gas emissions.

outcomes.description: The project significantly improved stakeholder understanding of greenhouse gas emissions from tropical livestock systems and viable mitigation solutions. Research outputs were communicated to policymakers, researchers, and development partners across Kenya, Africa, and internationally, demonstrating that current national GHG inventories using IPCC defaults likely underestimate emissions from tropical livestock systems by 15-23% for methane, while overestimating manure-based nitrous oxide emissions by factors of 10-30. Stakeholders gained understanding that indigenous breeds like Red Maasai sheep offer climate-smart advantages through lower emissions and greater resilience to parasites and nutritional stress. Decision-makers learned that locally-available feeding interventions using Calliandra supplementation can reduce methane emissions by up to 32% while simultaneously improving animal health and productivity. Communications were strategically framed within the needs of mitigation and adaptation of African livestock systems, informing future research priorities, on-farm intervention designs, and resource mobilization strategies. The research provided evidence that sheep excreta in tropical grasslands are minor GHG sources, challenging assumptions and supporting more accurate Tier 2 reporting for national inventories.
